subsection.text: In this article the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Assess” means:

paragraph.text: for real property, to determine the phased–in full cash value or use value to which the property tax rate may be applied; and
for personal property, to determine the value to which the property tax rate may be applied.

subsection.text: “Assessment” means:

paragraph.text: for real property, the phased–in full cash value or use value to which the property tax rate may be applied; and
for personal property, the value to which the property tax rate may be applied.

subsection.text: “Assessment roll” means the official listing of assessments of property required under § 2–202(3) of this article.
“Collector” includes an officer of a county or municipal corporation who has a duty to collect or remit taxes.

paragraph.text: “Corporation” includes an association or joint–stock company.
“Corporation” does not include a common trust fund as defined in § 3–501(b) of the Financial Institutions Article.

subsection.text: “County” means a county of the State and, unless expressly provided otherwise, Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: “County property tax” means the tax on property that is authorized under §§ 6–202 and 10–102 through 10–105 of this article.
“County property tax” does not include a tax imposed on property specifically benefited by local improvements.

subsection.text: “Date of finality” means January 1, when assessments become final for the taxable year next following.

paragraph.text: “Department” means the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
“Department” includes, unless the context requires otherwise, a supervisor.

subsection.text: “Director” means the Director of the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
“Domestic corporation” means a corporation organized under the laws of the State.
“Foreign corporation” means a corporation organized under the laws of the United States, a foreign country, or another state.
“Governing body” means:

paragraph.text: for Baltimore City, unless otherwise provided, the Board of Estimates;
for charter counties, as provided by local law, the county council or the county executive and the county council;
for code counties, the county commissioners or county council;
for county commissioner counties, the county commissioners; and
for municipal corporations, the body provided by municipal charter.

subsection.text: “Includes” or “including” means includes or including by way of illustration and not by way of limitation.
“Internal Revenue Code” means Title 26 of the United States Code.
“Law” includes any enactment, order, resolution, or ordinance of a county or municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: “Manufacturing” means the process of substantially transforming, or a substantial step in the process of substantially transforming, tangible personal property into a new and different article of tangible personal property by use of labor or machinery.
“Manufacturing” includes:

subparagraph.text: the operation of sawmills, grain mills, or feed mills;
the operation of machinery and equipment used to extract and process minerals, metals, or earthen materials or by–products that result from the extracting or processing;
research and development activities, whether or not the company has a product for sale;
the identification, design, or genetic engineering of biological materials for research or manufacture; and
the design, development, or creation of computer software for sale, lease, or license.

paragraph.text: “Manufacturing” does not include:

subparagraph.text: activities that are primarily a service;
activities that are intellectual, artistic, or clerical in nature;
public utility services, including telephone, gas, electric, water, and steam production services; or
any other activity that would not commonly be considered as manufacturing.

subsection.text: “Municipal corporation” means an entity that is subject to Article XI–E of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: “Municipal corporation property tax” means the tax on property authorized under §§ 6–203 and 10–102 through 10–105 of this article.
“Municipal corporation property tax” does not include a tax imposed on property specifically benefited by local improvements.

subsection.text: “Operating land” means any land used to operate a railroad or public utility.

paragraph.text: “Operating personal property” includes any property, other than real property, used to operate a railroad or public utility.
For a public utility, “operating personal property” includes cables, lines, poles, and towers.
“Operating property” means any property used to operate a railroad or public utility.
“Operating property” includes operating real property and operating personal property.

subsection.text: “Operating real property” includes any real property used to operate a railroad or public utility.

paragraph.text: “Operating unit” means, as determined by the Department, all of the operating property of a railroad or a public utility.
“Operating unit” includes operating property that is located outside of the State.
“Operating unit” does not include more than 1 railroad or public utility for which separate accounts are kept, unless the Department finds that:

subparagraph.text: the accounts are under the same or commonly controlled management; and
the inclusion is necessary to determine the value of the operating property.

subsection.text: “Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, or representative of any kind and any partnership, firm, corporation, or other entity.
“Principal office of a domestic corporation” means:

paragraph.text: the office in the State where the business of the corporation is directed and managed;
if there is no office in the State where the business is directed and managed, the place in the State where the principal business of the corporation in the State is transacted; or
if there is no office or place that meets the requirements of item (1) or (2) of this subsection, the principal office named in the corporation charter or reported to the Department.

subsection.text: “Principal office of a foreign corporation in the State” means the place in the State where the principal business or operation of the corporation in the State is carried on.
“Property” means real property and personal property.
“Property tax” means the property tax imposed by:

paragraph.text: the State;
a county; or
a municipal corporation.
“Public utility” means a company classified by the Department as a public utility under § 8–109 of this article.
“Public utility” includes:

subparagraph.text: an electric company;
a gas company;
a pipeline company;
a sewage disposal company;
a steam heating company;
a telephone company; and
a water company.

paragraph.text: “Public utility” does not include:

subparagraph.text: a cable television company;
a cellular telephone company;
a cogenerator;
an exempt wholesale generator;
an independent power producer;
a small power producer; or
a utility owned by a county or municipal corporation.

subsection.text: “Quarterly date of finality” means the April 1 or October 1 when assessments may be made for real property that becomes assessable up to that time and after the last date of finality or semiannual date of finality.

paragraph.text: “Real property” means any land or improvements to land.
“Real property” includes:

subparagraph.text: a leasehold or other limited interest in real property; and
an easement.

paragraph.text: “Research and development” means:

subparagraph.text: basic and applied research in the sciences and engineering; and
the design, development, and governmentally required premarket testing of prototypes, products, and processes.

paragraph.text: “Research and development” does not include:

subparagraph.text: market research;
research in the social sciences, psychology, or other nontechnical activities;
routine product testing;
sales services;
technical and nontechnical services; or
research and development of a public utility.

subsection.text: “Resident of the State” includes a domestic corporation.
“Semiannual date of finality” means July 1, when assessments may be made for real property that becomes assessable after the immediately preceding date of finality or quarterly date of finality.
“State” means:

paragraph.text: a state, possession, or territory of the United States;
the District of Columbia; or
the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

subsection.text: “State property tax” means the tax imposed on property under § 6–201 of this article and authorized under §§ 10–102 and 10–103 of this article.
“Supervisor” means the supervisor of assessments for a county.
“Tax roll” means the assessment roll to which the property tax rate has been applied and on which the property tax on each property is shown.
“Taxable year” means July 1 to June 30, both inclusive, for which the State, each county, municipal corporation, and taxing district of the State computes, imposes, and collects property tax.
“Valuation” means the process of determining the value of property.
“Value” means the full cash value of property.

A requirement in this article that a document be under oath means that the document shall be supported by a statement made under the penalties of perjury that the contents of the document are true to the best of the knowledge, information, and belief of the individual making the statement.
The oath or affirmation shall be made:

paragraph.text: before an individual authorized to administer oaths, who shall certify in writing to have administered the oath or taken the affirmation; or
by a signed statement that:

subparagraph.text: is in the document or attached to and made part of the document; and
is expressly made under the penalties for perjury.

subsection.text: If the procedures provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section are used, the affidavit subjects the individual making it to the penalties for perjury to the same extent as an oath or affirmation made before an individual authorized to administer oaths.

A person doing business in the State is deemed a resident of the State and of the county and any municipal corporation where the business is conducted if personal property is used in or in connection with the business.
A personal representative of the estate of a decedent is deemed a resident of the county where appointed.
A guardian is deemed a resident of the county where appointed.
In this section, “fiduciary” includes a personal representative, trustee, or guardian.
Except as otherwise provided in this article, a fiduciary is liable for the taxes on property held by the fiduciary as a fiduciary.
Except as otherwise provided in subsection (d) of this section or in the case of default or breach of duty, a fiduciary’s liability extends only to assets that the fiduciary holds as a fiduciary.

paragraph.text: A fiduciary who distributes property held as a fiduciary after the date of finality for the next following taxable year shall retain sufficient funds to pay any taxes on the property for that taxable year for any assessment against the property held in a fiduciary capacity, if the assessment is made before the date of finality.
If the fiduciary fails to retain sufficient funds to pay these taxes, the fiduciary and the bond of the fiduciary are liable for the taxes.

section.text: A “common trust fund” as defined in § 3-501(b) of the Financial Institutions Article is not subject to tax under this article.

subsection.text: In this section, “tax information” means:

paragraph.text: the amount of income or any particulars disclosed in any return required under any provision of law of this State if the return contains federal return information;
the amount of income or any particulars disclosed in any application required under § 9-104 of this article; or
any federal return information required to be attached to or included in a return of this State or to any application required under § 9-104 of this article.

subsection.text: An officer, employee, former officer, or former employee of the State or any political subdivision of the State may not make known, in any manner, any tax information, except:

paragraph.text: in accordance with proper judicial or legislative order; and
to an officer of the State or of any political subdivision of the State who by reason of the office has a right to tax information.

subsection.text: In this section, “taxes” includes interest and penalties on taxes.

The courts of this State shall recognize and enforce liability for taxes imposed by the laws of another state if the other state recognizes and enforces liability for similar taxes imposed by this State.

An official of another state described in subsection (b) of this section may bring an action in the courts of this State to collect taxes. A certification of the Secretary of State of the other state or comparable official in the District of Columbia is conclusive proof that the official has the authority to collect the taxes.
In this section, “legal holiday” means:

paragraph.text: the day on which a legal holiday, as defined in Article 1, § 27 of the Code, is observed; or
a federal legal holiday.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, when under State or local law, the last day to pay a tax, file a tax return or perform any other act that relates to taxes under this article falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, performance of the act is considered timely if the act is performed on the next succeeding day that is not a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday.
For purposes of this section, the last day to perform an act is the last day of any authorized extension of time.

section.text: The Comptroller is responsible for the collection of all State taxes at the rates required by law on the various classes of property determinations against which are certified directly to the Comptroller and on which taxes are payable directly into the Treasury of the State.

Notwithstanding any other law of the State, the State or any of its units, political subdivisions, or special taxing districts may act as necessary to collect from the United States money that is available for reimbursement for taxes or other charges that have been lost because the United States or 1 of its units holds title to property in the State.
It is the intent of the General Assembly that property owners in this State have:

paragraph.text: knowledge that the valuation and assessment of property is the responsibility of the State Department of Assessments and Taxation;
understanding of the valuation and assessment process;
assurance that the valuation and assessment of property within classes is uniform;
access to information which is the basis for the property valuation and assessment process in this State; and
understanding that the setting of property tax rates and the collection of property taxes is a local government function.

section.text: Property owners in this State have the following rights:

subparagraph.text: the right to an assessment notice upon reassessment, as provided in § 8-401 of this article, that clearly explains:

sub-subparagraph.text: the property owner’s right to appeal an assessment;
that the determination of value is based upon information contained in the valuation records of the Department; and
the property owner’s right of access to the valuation records of the Department; and

subparagraph.text: the right to receive information concerning the calculation of the assessment and description of the property on the Department’s website;

paragraph.text: the right to obtain, at no charge:

subparagraph.text: a brochure explaining the valuation and assessment process;
the record card and assessment work sheet for the property that is the subject of an assessment; and
a brochure explaining the record card and assessment work sheet, their pertinent parts, and an example and definition of commonly used appraisal terms;

paragraph.text: the right of access to the property assessment roll;
the right to appeal an assessment within 45 days of the notice of assessment, as provided in § 14-502 of this article, and to assist in an appeal, to obtain:

subparagraph.text: at no charge, a brochure explaining the assessment appeal process;
at no charge, a copy of the sales analysis for the area in which the property is located; and
for a reasonable fee, copies of record cards and assessment work sheets for other similar properties, as provided in § 14-201 of this article;

paragraph.text: the right to be provided with an alternate site or an evening or Saturday assessment appeal hearing, as provided in § 8-412 of this article;
the right to an assessment appeal hearing conducted by telephone, in accordance with the standards and procedures of the Department;
the right to postponement of an assessment appeal hearing one time without cause at the property owner’s request, and additional postponements only for good cause;
during an appeal hearing, the right to a review and explanation by the assessor of the items and values shown on the assessment work sheet and record card;
after an appeal hearing, the right to:

subparagraph.text: not have an assessment increased during the current 3-year cycle because of information ascertained at an appeal hearing on residential property; and
a reinspection of a property, upon request, to review updated information revealed during an appeal hearing that could result in a decreased assessment;

paragraph.text: notwithstanding the failure to file an appeal within 45 days, the right to require the Department to review and correct any mathematical, clerical, measurement, or other technical errors used as the basis for an assessment, as provided in § 8-419 of this article;
the right to file a petition for review within any year of the 3-year assessment cycle, as provided in § 8-415 of this article;

the right to the consideration of the facts and reasons stated in a decision on an appeal from the Property Tax Appeal Board or the Maryland Tax Court when the assessment of a property is next reviewed, as provided in § 8-205 of this article; and
the right to be notified of the availability of State property tax credits, including the homestead property tax credit, the homeowners property tax credit, and the renters tax credit.

section.text: This subtitle shall be known as the Property Owner’s Bill of Rights.
There is a Department of Assessments and Taxation established as a department of the State government.

subsection.text: The head of the Department is the Director of Assessments and Taxation, who shall be appointed by the Governor.

paragraph.text: The Director shall be an individual who has executive ability and who is trained and experienced in the tax field.
After reaching the age of 70 years, an individual may not continue to hold the office of Director.

subsection.text: Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

section.text: The Director may employ staff and consultants in accordance with the State budget.

subsection.text: The Director shall designate 1 employee of the Department to be “State Supervisor of Assessments” and other employees of the Department to be “assessments area supervisors”.

Subject to the direction of the Director, the State Supervisor of Assessments and the assessments area supervisors shall supervise the performance of duties of the supervisors and the various assessors appointed under this title.

The State Supervisor of Assessments and the assessments area supervisors are in the management service of the State Personnel Management System. However, they shall hold their positions during good behavior and may be removed from their positions only after a hearing before the Department and a finding of incompetency or other cause.
There is a supervisor for each county.

paragraph.text: In this subsection and subsection (c) of this section, “appropriate county official” means the Mayor of Baltimore City, the county commissioners or county council of each county, or, if the county charter provides for a county executive, the county executive with the approval of the county council.
Each supervisor:

subparagraph.text: shall be appointed by the Director; and
shall be in the management service of the State Personnel Management System.

paragraph.text: The Director shall appoint each supervisor from a list of 5 qualified individuals submitted to the Director by the appropriate county official. The Director shall give the appropriate county official written notice that a vacancy exists in that county. Unless the Director extends the period on written request from the appropriate county official, the appropriate county official shall submit its list of nominees to the Director on or before 60 days from the date the Director notifies the official of the vacancy.

If the Director finds that none of the nominees on a list meets the qualifications set under § 2-109 of this subtitle, the Director may reject all of them and request the appropriate county official to provide a new list. If the appropriate county official does not submit a new list within 20 days of receiving the Director’s request, the Director may appoint any qualified individual.
In addition to the qualifications set under § 2-109 of this subtitle, a supervisor:

subparagraph.text: may not hold any other public office of profit;
on appointment, need not be a resident of the county for which the supervisor was appointed, but shall become a resident of the county after the appointment is made; and
may not continue to hold office after reaching the age of 70 years.

paragraph.text: The appropriate county official may waive the residency requirement of paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection.

If the appropriate county official nominates an individual under subsection (b)(3) of this section who is not currently a resident of the county, the residency requirement of paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection is waived for that individual.

subsection.text: A supervisor may be removed from office only after a hearing before the Department and a finding of incompetency or other cause.
The classifications and salaries of supervisors shall be set in accordance with the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article.

Each county shall provide the supervisor of the county with an office in the county seat or in Baltimore City, for the supervisor of Baltimore City. The Department is responsible for providing each supervisor with clerical staff, equipment, and other facilities and assistance that the Department considers necessary and as provided in the State budget.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, each county and Baltimore City shall be responsible for reimbursing the State for the costs of administering the Department as follows:

subparagraph.text: 50% of the costs of real property valuation;
50% of the costs of business personal property valuation; and

50% of the costs of the Office of Information Technology within the Department, including any funding for departmental projects in the Major Information Technology Development Project Fund established under § 3A–309 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: For each of fiscal years 2012 and 2013, each county and Baltimore City shall be responsible for reimbursing the State 90% instead of 50% of the costs of administering the Department described in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Costs under subsection (b) of this section shall be allocated among the counties and Baltimore City as follows:

paragraph.text: costs under subsection (b)(1)(i) and (iii) of this section will be allocated based on the number of real property accounts of a county or Baltimore City as a percentage of the total number of real property accounts statewide as of July 1 of the preceding fiscal year; and

costs under subsection (b)(1)(ii) of this section will be allocated based on the business personal property assessable base of a county or Baltimore City as a percentage of the total business personal property assessable bases statewide as of July 1 of the preceding fiscal year.

subsection.text: Each county and Baltimore City shall remit a quarterly payment to the Comptroller for 25% of the jurisdiction’s share of costs on the following dates:

paragraph.text: July 1;
October 1;
January 1; and
April 1.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may withhold a portion of a local income tax distribution of a county or Baltimore City that fails to make timely payment in accordance with this section.

section.text: The Department shall employ professional assessors including competent and experienced persons as assessors of commercial or industrial property, as provided in the State budget, and may assign the assessors to the supervisors as necessary to enable the supervisors to carry out their responsibilities under this title.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each assessor shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.
The assessor shall take the oath before the clerk or a deputy clerk of the circuit court for the county:

paragraph.text: in which the assessor resides; or
that is designated by the Director.

section.text: The Secretary of Budget and Management, after consultation with the Department, shall:

paragraph.text: set schedules of classifications and salaries for all employees of the Department in accordance with the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; and
set minimum education or experience qualifications for:

subparagraph.text: all supervisors;
all assessor classifications; and
all clerical classifications in the Department.

subsection.text: The salary schedules set for assessors under § 2-109 of this subtitle shall provide an appropriate incentive to encourage assessors to achieve the designation of certified assessment evaluator.
A county may not provide a salary supplement or any other fringe benefit for an assessor.

section.text: The Director, after consultation with the Secretary of Budget and Management, may adopt a regulation that permits the substitution of building trades or real estate experience for any educational qualifications that are set for assessors under § 2-109 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Director is responsible for the operation of the Department.

paragraph.text: The Director shall administer and enforce:

subparagraph.text: the provisions of this article; and
any other provision of law that is assigned to the Director or the Department for administration or enforcement.

paragraph.text: The Director may exercise any right or power that is conferred on the Director or the Department.

section.text: In addition to the powers and duties set forth elsewhere, the Director has the following powers and duties:

paragraph.text: to direct that the Department assess all property that is subject to assessment under this article;
to administer the assessment and tax laws of the State and of each county and municipal corporation;

to direct that the Department enter all taxable property on the assessment rolls and, regardless of whether the property is owned by an individual, corporation, or some other person, to value alike all property of a like kind;
to set standards or units for assessing various kinds of property;
subject to the approval of the Comptroller, to adopt a uniform system of accounts to be used by all collectors of State taxes;
to confer with appropriate county officials and to visit each county as often as necessary;
to direct that the Department require any person to provide complete information as to that person’s ownership of taxable property and to its value;
to direct that the Department investigate, on its own initiative, at any time, any assessment on any property in the State;
to confer, as appropriate, with the Governor, Comptroller, and Treasurer;
subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to submit to the General Assembly an annual report and any legislation that the Department may recommend for enactment;
to direct that the Department participate in any Maryland Tax Court or judicial proceeding that involves an assessment or tax;
to direct that the Department provide for annual surveys, conducted in the manner required by the Director, to determine the assessment ratios in each county; and

to direct that the Department supply all public branch libraries in the State as soon after issuance as possible with 1 or more copies of the most current Maryland Assessment Manual, the Assessors’ Administrative Procedures manual, and the annual supplements to the manuals.
The Department shall continually review all real property assessments to provide a review of each assessment at least once in each 3-year cycle.
If any assessment has not been reviewed during a 3-year cycle, the Department may order a review of the assessment at any time.

subsection.text: For the review under subsection (a) of this section, real property is not required to be reviewed individually or separately, but it may be grouped:

paragraph.text: in areas;
by character or use; or
in any other manner that the Department considers to be helpful or necessary.

subsection.text: On request of the property tax assessment appeal board for the county in which the property is located, the Director shall order a review of any real property assessment.

When reviewing real property under this section, the Department may use property description cards, property location maps, land classification maps, unit value maps, land use maps, zoning maps, records of new construction, sales records, building cost information, private appraisals, periodic surveys of assessment ratios, or any other material or information that the Department considers to be a reliable aid in determining real property value.

The Director may order a revaluation of any real property if, based on consideration and evaluation of a review of a real property valuation on which the existing assessment is based, it appears that the existing valuation of the real property is erroneous because it differs significantly from valuations on comparable properties.

Before ordering a revaluation of real property under this section, the Director shall consult with the governing body of the county or property tax assessment appeal board of the county in which the real property is located.
In this section, “taxing authority” means:

paragraph.text: the county council or board of county commissioners of a county;
the City Council of Baltimore City; and
the governing body of a municipal corporation.
On or before February 14 of each year, the Department shall send each taxing authority:

subparagraph.text: an estimate of the total assessment of all real property in the county or municipal corporation for the next taxable year; and
an estimate of the total assessment:

sub-subparagraph.text: of all new construction and improvements in the county or municipal corporation not assessed since the last date of finality; and
of all real property in the county or municipal corporation that may be deleted from the assessment records.

paragraph.text: The Department shall notify each taxing authority of any change in the estimated assessment of all real property in the county or the municipal corporation that results from actions of a property tax assessment appeal board or the Maryland Tax Court.

The Department shall notify each taxing authority of the constant yield tax rate that will provide the same property tax revenue that is provided by the real property tax rate that is in effect for the current taxable year.

In calculating a constant yield tax rate for a taxable year, the Department shall use an estimate of the total assessment of all real property for the next taxable year exclusive of real property that appears for the 1st time on the assessment records.
On or before May 15 of each year, the Department may amend a constant yield tax rate but only:

subparagraph.text: when directed to make a change by an enactment of the General Assembly;
to correct an error in the calculation of the constant yield tax rate; or
to reflect a significant loss of taxable base, as determined by the Director.

subsection.text: The Director shall exempt a municipal corporation from the constant yield tax rate provisions of § 6-308 of this article if a difference of less than $25,000 exists between:

paragraph.text: the property tax revenue that is provided by applying the municipal corporation real property tax rate for the preceding taxable year to the estimated assessment of all real property in the municipal corporation; and
the property tax revenue that is provided by applying the constant yield tax rate for the next taxable year to the estimated assessment of all real property in the municipal corporation.
The Director shall report to the Attorney General any taxing authority that appears to have violated the requirements of § 6-308 of this article.

The Attorney General shall investigate the report forwarded by the Director. If the Attorney General finds that a taxing authority violated the requirements of § 6-308 of this article, the Attorney General shall institute appropriate legal action to effect compliance with the requirements of § 6-308 of this article.
If a court finds that a taxing authority violated § 6-308 of this article, the real property tax rate of that taxing authority shall be the constant yield tax rate.

subsection.text: A taxing authority that does not exceed the constant yield tax rate shall notify the Department within the time set by the Director.

section.text: On request by the Maryland Tax Court, the Department shall perform administrative duties for the Maryland Tax Court.

subsection.text: In this section, “taxing official” means:

paragraph.text: as to the federal government:

subparagraph.text: any official of the United States Treasury Department; or
any collector of federal taxes; and

paragraph.text: as to the government of any state, any state official who is responsible under the law of that state for:

subparagraph.text: the assessment process;
the imposition of taxes; or
the collection of taxes.

paragraph.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section and notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Department may provide a tax official of another state or of the federal government with information that relates to:

subparagraph.text: the assessment process;
the imposition of taxes;
the collection of taxes; or
any other tax matter.

paragraph.text: The information that the Department may provide under this section may be obtained from:

subparagraph.text: any tax report or return that is filed under law; or
any tax audit or investigation.

subsection.text: The Department may provide information under this section only if:

paragraph.text: the Department is satisfied that the information will be used for tax purposes only; and
the federal or state government to which the information is to be released provides similar information to the tax officials of this State.

section.text: The Department shall attempt to determine the most effective and equitable method to assess property and collect taxes. In particular, the Department shall attempt to determine the best method of reaching all property that is subject to assessment and tax while avoiding taxing the same property twice. For these purposes, the Department may inquire into the laws of other jurisdictions regarding the situs of property for tax purposes and confer with the assessing and tax authorities of other jurisdictions.

subsection.text: The Department shall adopt and periodically revise a uniform plan to assess property.
All assessors and property tax assessment appeal boards shall follow strictly the uniform plan.
The Department shall prepare, install, and maintain for each county a complete record of properties, with appropriate indexes and cross indexes, and a system of appraisal aids that consist of:

paragraph.text: property description cards;
property location maps;
land classification maps;
unit value maps; and
records of:

subparagraph.text: new construction;
sales;
building costs; and
private appraisals.

paragraph.text: The Department shall publish instructions and directions that set forth generally the duties to be performed and the procedures to be followed in making and recording assessments.
The instructions and directions shall be distributed to the governing body of each county, all assessment officers, and any official who has any duty that relates to assessments.

subsection.text: The Director shall establish and provide all forms for notices, records, reports, and other matters that relate to the functions of supervisors and assessors.

paragraph.text: Each supervisor shall keep a record of all real property assessments in the county.
The record shall be arranged alphabetically, according to owners, by election district or subdistrict, taxing district, or assessment area. However, the supervisor may arrange the record:

subparagraph.text: listing the real properties in lot and block order by subdivisions, if the record also contains an alphabetical index that shows the page where the accounts listed may be located;
in Baltimore City, by wards and by blocks that correspond, as far as possible, to the block numbers used in the Baltimore City Circuit Court records; or
in an electronic medium.

paragraph.text: Each account in the record shall show for the real property:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the owner;
a brief description of the property;
the specific location of the property;
the general location of the property including a deed or will reference and any tax map reference; and
the assessment of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the land; and
any improvement on the land.

paragraph.text: The details of land and improvements on the land that have been valued at different amounts shall be recorded on the respective worksheet or card.

subsection.text: The record shall be rewritten periodically and the current record and prior records shall be retained. However, except for a record that contains current values, any record may be microfilmed as provided by State law and the original destroyed. The microfilm shall be the permanent record.
The record and prior records shall be available for public inspection without charge.

Copies of the assessment record shall be made available to the public at a reasonable cost. If the Department approves of the purpose for which the information is requested, the Department may make available to the public, at a reasonable cost, copies of data processing tapes or other magnetic media containing the record of the assessment records.

paragraph.text: If the accuracy or completeness of information used to assess real property is disputed by the owner of the real property or if the owner has additional information that the owner believes is relevant to the value of the real property, the owner may file a brief statement containing the nature of the dispute or the additional information.
The supervisor shall retain the statement as part of the assessment record.

subsection.text: Personal property assessment records shall be maintained and arranged in alphabetical order according to the owner by county, election district, taxing district, or assessment area.
Each record shall contain:

paragraph.text: a brief description of the nature of the personal property; and
the value of the personal property.

subsection.text: A personal property assessment record may be inspected only by:

paragraph.text: the property owner or the property taxpayer if different from the owner, for the personal property; or
an officer of the State, a county, or a municipal corporation that is affected by the personal property assessment.

subsection.text: The Department may allow a commercial bank to have access to personal property returns for the limited purpose of assisting in the collection of filing fees through a lockbox system.
Each supervisor shall maintain for public inspection, without charge:

paragraph.text: a complete set of tax maps for the county together with parcel reference lists; and
on request of an interested party, sales records or transfer voucher forms that relate to sales of real property.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide copies of the information set forth in subsection (a) of this section to the public for a reasonable fee that reflects the cost of reproduction.

section.text: To explain and support the Department’s recommendations, the supervisor for a county, or an assessor assigned to that supervisor, shall attend any hearing before the property tax assessment appeal board of that county.

When an assessment appeal is filed with a supervisor and the amount of the proposed value of the property is more than $2,000,000, the Department shall notify the appropriate county legal officer of the filing.

subsection.text: In addition to carrying out the instructions of and the duties assigned by the Department, each supervisor has the powers and duties set forth in this section.
Each supervisor is the chief assessor and shall supervise the assessing of all property in the county for which the supervisor is appointed.
Each supervisor shall:

paragraph.text: visit frequently each district of the county for which the supervisor is appointed to obtain all necessary information as to the existence and valuation of property that is subject to tax;
keep informed as to:

subparagraph.text: sales in the county; and
the conditions that relate to those sales; and

paragraph.text: report to the Department the sales and the consideration involved.

subsection.text: Each supervisor shall attempt diligently to list all escaped and new property in the county for which the supervisor is appointed.
Each supervisor shall cooperate with appropriate county officials and other assessing authorities to make equitable assessments.

If the supervisor considers the assessment or ruling to be improper, the supervisor may appeal to the Maryland Tax Court any assessment or ruling of the property tax assessment appeal board of the county for which the supervisor is appointed.
A supervisor may:

paragraph.text: correct annually the value of any improperly valued property; and
value any property that has been omitted or later acquired.

subsection.text: In this section, “inspection” means an exterior physical inspection of real property for the purpose of determining the condition and attributes of real property and verifying the measurements of any improvements to land.
Assessors are authorized to enter on land for the limited purpose of making inspections.
The Department shall adopt regulations to implement this section.
The Department may request documentation to verify that a dwelling is the principal residence of a homeowner.
The documentation requested under subsection (a) of this section may include, but is not limited to, requiring an individual to execute a sworn affidavit regarding residency for the purposes of:

paragraph.text: voting;
driver’s license address; and
income tax filing.

subsection.text: Failure to provide the requested information under this section within 30 days from the date of a request shall result in a dwelling being designated as not a principal residence for purposes of this article.

section.text: The Department shall pay the amount received by the Department in payment of annual filing fees of Maryland corporations under § 1-203 of the Corporations and Associations Article into the General Fund of the State.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: pay immediately to the Treasurer for distribution as provided by this Part II of this subtitle all organization and capitalization fees and all recording, filing, or other fees that are collected by the Department under § 1-203 of the Corporations and Associations Article; and
account quarterly to the Comptroller for all money collected and paid under this subtitle.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Base year” means the taxable year immediately before the taxable year in which property first becomes qualified property under this section.

subparagraph.text: “Base year value” means the value of the property used to determine the assessment on which the property tax on real property was imposed for the base year.
“Base year value” does not include any new real property that was first assessed in the base year.

paragraph.text: “BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone” has the meaning stated in § 5–1301 of the Economic Development Article.

“BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone Tax Rate” means the property tax rate of the political subdivision where a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone is located for the taxable year when the Secretary of Business and Economic Development first designates the area as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone.
“Eligible assessment” means the difference between the base year value and the actual value as determined by the Department for the applicable taxable year.
“Property tax increment” means the property tax attributable to the eligible assessment of qualified property.
“Qualified property” means real property that is:

subparagraph.text: located in a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone that is designated under Title 5, Subtitle 13 of the Economic Development Article; and

in one of the categories of commercial or residential property that the Department of Business and Economic Development has determined, in consultation with the Base Realignment and Closure Subcabinet and as provided in regulations adopted by the Department of Business and Economic Development, enhance the economic development of the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone.

paragraph.text: “Tax increment financing bonds” means bonds issued:

subparagraph.text: by a county or municipal corporation under Title 12, Subtitle 2 of the Economic Development Article; or
by Baltimore City under Article II, § 62 of the Charter of Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: The amounts received by a political subdivision under this section may be used only for the purposes provided in § 5–1306 of the Economic Development Article.

Subject to subsections (c) and (f) of this section, for each fiscal year for a period of 10 consecutive fiscal years beginning in fiscal 2010, the State shall provide to each political subdivision in which a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone has been established an amount equal to:

subparagraph.text: the State property tax increment on the qualified properties in the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone; and
one–half of the political subdivision’s property tax increment on qualified properties, determined using the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone Tax Rate for the political subdivision.

paragraph.text: The total amount paid to all political subdivisions for any fiscal year under this section may not exceed the lesser of:

subparagraph.text: the amount appropriated for the purpose of this section for that fiscal year in the State budget as approved by the General Assembly; or

paragraph.text: If the total amount to be paid to all political subdivisions as determined under subsection (b)(2) of this section without regard to the limitation under paragraph (1) of this subsection exceeds the limitation under paragraph (1) of this subsection, each political subdivision shall receive an amount equal to the product of multiplying the amount determined for that political subdivision under subsection (b)(2) of this section times a fraction:

subparagraph.text: the numerator of which is the limitation under paragraph (1) of this subsection; and

the denominator of which is the total amount to be paid to all subdivisions as determined under subsection (b)(2) of this section without regard to the limitation under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: After a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone is designated by the Secretary of Business and Economic Development, on or before February 1 of each year, the appropriate governing body shall certify to the Department:

subparagraph.text: any real property in the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone that is qualified property for the next taxable year; and
the date that the real property became qualified property.
On or before March 1 of each year, the Department shall calculate the amount determined for each political subdivision under subsection (b)(2) of this section for the next fiscal year.
The Comptroller shall pay the amounts due the political subdivisions under this section quarterly.

subsection.text: Any amount provided under this section does not limit or otherwise affect any authority of a political subdivision under any other provision of law to pledge any other assets or revenues towards the repayment of tax increment financing bonds.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to a political subdivision that is authorized under § 7–211.3 of this article to enter into a payment in lieu of tax agreement with a private developer of federal enclave property.

The State may not provide amounts under this section to a political subdivision until, in the judgment of the Secretary of Business and Economic Development, the local jurisdiction has entered into good–faith negotiations for a payment in lieu of tax agreement with all private developers of federal enclave property.

subsection.text: The Department and the Department of Business and Economic Development jointly shall adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this section and to specify criteria and procedures for application, approval, and monitoring the eligibility for the amounts under this section.
In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administrator” means the Administrator of the property tax assessment appeal boards.
“Board” means a property tax assessment appeal board.
“Member” means a member or alternate member of a property tax assessment appeal board.

section.text: There is a property tax assessment appeal board in each county.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, each board consists of 3 regular members and 1 alternate member.
In Anne Arundel County, Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Montgomery County, and Prince George’s County, each board consists of 3 regular members and 3 alternate members.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the members from a list of names submitted as follows:

subparagraph.text: for Baltimore City, by the Mayor of Baltimore City; or
for a county other than Baltimore City, by:

sub-subparagraph.text: the county commissioners or the county council of the county; or
if the county charter provides for a county executive, by the county executive with the approval of the county council.

paragraph.text: The number of names on each list shall be 3 times the number of vacancies.
Each list shall be submitted at least 3 months before the end of a term.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each appointee to the board shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years. The term ends on June 1 of the appropriate year.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the board on July 1, 1985.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

An alternate member fills a vacancy of a regular member until the vacancy is permanently filled. However, if an alternate member is appointed by the Governor as the regular member, the Governor shall appoint a new alternate member.

The board chairman or the Administrator may ask an alternate member to serve on the board during the temporary absence of a regular member. However, an alternate may not serve on the board when the 3 regular members are present.
The Governor may remove a member only for incompetence, malfeasance, conduct unbecoming a board member, or inability or failure to perform the duties of the office on a regular basis.

After giving a member notice and an opportunity for a hearing, the Mayor of Baltimore City, the county commissioners or the county council of the county, or if the county charter provides for a county executive, the county executive with the approval of the county council, may recommend the removal of the member by the Governor for the grounds listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

section.text: From among the regular members of each board, the Governor shall appoint a chairman for each board.

subsection.text: Two members of a board are a quorum to do business.

paragraph.text: The board shall issue an order that sets forth its determination of any matter brought before it. Two members of a board shall sign the order.
The order shall be filed with the clerk of the board.

subsection.text: Each member of a board is entitled to:

paragraph.text: compensation at an hourly rate as provided in the State budget; and
reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Administrator, each board may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
A member is subject to the Maryland Public Ethics Law.
Except as otherwise authorized by law, a member or staff of the board may not divulge information specified in § 14-201 of this article.
Each board has jurisdiction in its county over appeals concerning:

paragraph.text: real property values and assessments;
credits for elderly or disabled renters under § 9-102 of this article;
credits for homeowners under §§ 9-104 and 9-105 of this article;
credits for elderly or disabled homeowners under § 9-101 of this article;
credits authorized under § 9-222 of this article for real property leased to a religious group or religious organization;
the value of easements under § 2-511 of the Agriculture Article; or
the rejection of an application for a property tax exemption as provided by § 7-103 and Title 14, Subtitle 5 of this article.
A board may not decrease the amount of an assessment after the date of finality for any year unless an appeal of the assessment is filed before the date of finality.

Between general reviews of an assessment in a district, a board may not decrease an assessment in the district unless the board notifies and consults with the supervisor for the district before decreasing the assessment. If a board decreases an assessment between general reviews without first notifying and consulting with the supervisor the decrease is void.

subsection.text: With the advice and consent of the Senate, the Governor shall appoint an Administrator of the boards for a term of 6 years.
The Administrator is entitled to the salary and necessary assistance as provided in the State budget.
In addition to the powers and duties set forth elsewhere in this article, the Administrator shall:

paragraph.text: prepare and provide notices and reports required of boards including uniform forms, order blanks, and statements advising taxpayers of their right to appeal;
keep a record of complaints about the conduct or fitness of members; and
forward to the appropriate county officials listed in § 3-103(d)(2) of this title complaints that would justify removal of a member.
Subject to Title 10, Subtitles 1 and 2 of the State Government Article, the Administrator shall:

subparagraph.text: adopt uniform regulations to govern the activities of the boards; and
ensure that the regulations are applied consistently.

paragraph.text: After adoption, regulations shall be filed with the Maryland Tax Court and Court of Appeals.

subsection.text: There is a collector for each county in the State.
Except as otherwise provided by law, for each county, the governing body of the county shall appoint a collector on or before January 1 of each year.
Before taking office, each collector shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: A collector is entitled to the compensation provided in the county budget.
A collector may not receive separate compensation from the State for collecting State taxes.

subsection.text: For the collection of the State property tax, a collector shall be bonded as required by the Comptroller. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the State.
For the collection of the county property tax, a collector shall be bonded as required by the county. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the county.
Each collector shall collect:

paragraph.text: for property listed on the tax roll, the State and county taxes that are due and any interest, penalties, and service charges on the property tax that are due; and
any tax on personal property imposed by § 10-210 of this article.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, on request of a municipal corporation or special taxing district, a collector may collect municipal corporation or special taxing district taxes.
Except as otherwise provided by law, the collector shall remit the taxes collected during any month, and interest, penalties, or service charges on the taxes collected:

paragraph.text: for the county, to the appropriate county official on or before the 10th day of the following month;
for a municipal corporation, to the appropriate municipal corporation official; and
for a special district, to the appropriate officer of the district.

subsection.text: The collector for each county shall:

paragraph.text: deposit State taxes, and any interest, penalty, or service charges on the taxes, collected at the intervals and in the manner designated by the Comptroller; and
on or before the 10th day of each month, submit a report to the Comptroller of State taxes, and any interest, penalty, or service charges on the taxes, collected during the prior month.

subsection.text: A violation of this section by a collector is subject to the penalties in §§ 14-1015 and 14-1016 of this article.

section.text: At any time, the Comptroller, the State Treasurer, or an individual designated in writing by either of them, may examine a collector’s records on State taxes.

subsection.text: The governing body of a county, the chief administrative officer in Montgomery County, or the supervisor in Baltimore City for any local taxes that are due, shall make allowances for:

paragraph.text: insolvencies or removals as to personal property;
refunds made under law; or
decreasing or abating assessments under § 8-419 of this article.

subsection.text: On certificates by the governing body of a county, the chief administrative officer in Montgomery County, or the supervisor in Baltimore City, the Comptroller, for any State taxes that are due, shall make allowances for:

paragraph.text: insolvencies and removals as to personal property;
refunds made under law; or
decreasing or abating of assessments under § 8-419 of this article.

section.text: If a collector fails to remit taxes or the interest, penalty, and service charges on the taxes, to the State or the county as provided under this title, the collector shall be charged interest at the rate of 6% a year on all taxes, interest, penalties, and service charges not paid to the State or county from the time they are due.

subsection.text: In addition to any other remedy, if a collector fails to remit taxes as provided by §§ 4-201 and 4-202 of this title, the Comptroller may request the Attorney General to file suit against the collector and the bond of the collector.
If suit is brought by the State, a county, or a municipal corporation as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the collector or surety has the right to a jury trial.

For property tax purposes, the owner of a life estate, or other particular freehold estate, or term of years perpetually renewable in property is deemed the owner of the property and is liable for property tax on the property.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “person in possession or control of property” includes a lessee, custodian, consignee, or bailee.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, for property tax purposes, the Department may determine by regulation if a person in possession or control of property is to be deemed the owner of the property by the Department.

If a person in possession or control of property is deemed the owner under the Department’s regulations and if the property is assessed separately from other property of the person, a collector may collect property tax from:

subparagraph.text: the owner of the property; or
the person who is deemed the owner of the property.

subsection.text: Except as provided by agreement, a person who is deemed the owner of property and who pays property tax:

paragraph.text: has a right to indemnity from the owner for the tax paid; and
for tangible personal property, has a lien on the property for property tax while the property is in the possession or control of the person.

subsection.text: Real property is subject to assessment and taxation in the State, the county, and, if applicable, municipal corporation or special tax district where the real property is situated.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, subsection (c) of this section, and for operating property in § 6-103 of this article, tangible personal property located in the State is subject to assessment and taxation in the county and, if applicable, municipal corporation where the tangible personal property is permanently located.
If tangible personal property located in the State is not permanently located in any county, it is subject to assessment and taxation where the owner resides.

subsection.text: The stock in business of a manufacturing or commercial business is subject to assessment and taxation in the county and, if applicable, municipal corporation where the business is carried on.

If trustees of personal property include trustees who are nonresidents of the State, the property shall be treated as held by a resident of the State in the same proportion that the number of trustees who are residents of the State bears to the total number of trustees. The remainder of the property shall be treated as held by a nonresident of the State.

section.text: The person responsible for issuing building permits shall immediately after issuing a building permit submit a copy of the building permit to the supervisor of the county where the building is located.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this article, all property located in this State is subject to assessment and property tax and is taxable to the owner of the property.

Property subject to assessment and tax under this article includes property owned or leased by the United States or any agency or department of the United States, to the fullest extent possible under the Constitution of the United States and the laws of the United States.

subsection.text: Intangible personal property is not subject to assessment and property tax.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, a leasehold or other limited interest in property is not subject to property tax.

An interest of a life tenant or the owner of any other freehold estate in property is subject to property tax as though the person in possession or the user of the property were the owner of the property.

An interest of the mortgagor, pledgor, or conditional sale buyer in personal property is subject to property tax as though the person in possession or the user of the personal property were the owner of the personal property.
The following interests in real property are subject to property tax as though the person in possession or the user of the property were the owner of the property:

paragraph.text: an interest of a tenant under a 99-year lease, whether or not the lease is renewable;
an interest of a tenant under a lease for less than 99 years, if the lease is perpetually renewable; and
an interest of a mortgagor or grantor under a deed of trust.

subsection.text: Unless exempted under § 7–211, § 7–211.1, § 7–244, or § 7–501 of this article, the interest or privilege of a person in property that is owned by the federal government, the State, a county, a municipal corporation, or an agency or instrumentality of the federal government, the State, a county, or a municipal corporation is subject to property tax as though the lessee or the user of the property were the owner of the property, if the property is leased or otherwise made available to that person:

paragraph.text: by the federal government, the State, a county, a municipal corporation, or an agency or instrumentality of the federal government, the State, a county, or a municipal corporation; and
with the privilege to use the property in connection with a business that is conducted for profit.

section.text: Operating property of a railroad or public utility located in the State is subject to property tax.
Except as otherwise provided in §§ 7-222 and 7-226 of this article, any stock in business of a person who engages in a manufacturing or commercial business in the State is subject to property tax.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this article, the State may impose State property tax on the assessment of property that is subject to the State property tax.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county is not required to pass any law to incorporate the State property tax in the property tax bill or to collect the State property tax.

section.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county may impose property tax on the assessment of property that is subject to that county’s property tax.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this article, the governing body of a municipal corporation may impose municipal corporation property tax on those classes of property that it selects to be subject to municipal corporation property tax.
The municipal corporation property tax is imposed only on assessments made under Title 8 of this article.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided by this article, property tax is imposed for the taxable year.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Board of Public Works annually shall set the rates for State property tax for the next taxable year as authorized by the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: Intangible personal property is subject to State property tax as otherwise provided in this title at the rate set annually by the Board of Public Works under subsection (a) of this section, if:

subparagraph.text: the intangible personal property has paid interest or dividends during the 12 months that precede the date of finality;
interest or dividends were withheld on the intangible personal property during the 12 months that precede the date of finality to avoid the tax under this subsection;
the intangible personal property consists of newly issued bonds, certificates of indebtedness, or evidences of debt on which interest is not in default; or
a stock dividend has been declared on the intangible personal property during the 12 months that precede the date of finality.

paragraph.text: The State property tax rate for the intangible personal property may not exceed 15 cents for each $100 of an assessment.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section and after complying with § 6-305 of this subtitle, in each year after the date of finality and before the following July 1, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of each county annually shall set the tax rate for the next taxable year on all assessments of property subject to that county’s property tax.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, §§ 6-305 and 6-306 of this subtitle and § 6-203 of this title:

subparagraph.text: there shall be a single county property tax rate for all real property subject to county property tax except for operating real property described in § 8-109(c) of this article; and

the county tax rate applicable to personal property and the operating real property described in § 8-109(c) of this article for taxable years beginning after June 30, 2001 shall be 2.5 times the rate for real property.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not affect a special rate prevailing in a taxing district or part of a county.
Intangible personal property is subject to county property tax as otherwise provided in this title at a rate set annually, if:

subparagraph.text: the intangible personal property has paid interest or dividends during the 12 months that precede the date of finality;
interest or dividends were withheld on the intangible personal property during the 12 months that precede the date of finality to avoid the tax under this subsection;
the intangible personal property consists of newly issued bonds, certificates of indebtedness, or evidences of debt on which interest is not in default; or
a stock dividend has been declared on the intangible personal property during the 12 months that precede the date of finality.

paragraph.text: The county tax rate for the intangible personal property is 30 cents for each $100 of assessment.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, in each year after the date of finality and before the following July 1, the governing body of each municipal corporation annually shall set the tax rate for the next taxable year on all assessments of property subject to municipal corporation property tax.
If not otherwise prohibited by this article, the governing body of a municipal corporation may set special rates for any class of property that is subject to the municipal corporation property tax.

subsection.text: The governing body of a municipal corporation may change a property tax rate that is fixed in its charter if:

paragraph.text: the rate causes a loss of revenue because of exemption of property that is subject to the tax rate; or
a loss of revenue is caused by any special rate of municipal corporation property tax.
Unless otherwise provided by the governing body of the municipal corporation:

subparagraph.text: there shall be a single municipal corporation property tax rate for all real property subject to municipal corporation property tax except for operating real property described in § 8-109(c) of this article; and

the municipal tax rate applicable to personal property and the operating real property described in § 8-109(c) of this article for taxable years beginning after June 30, 2001 shall be 2.5 times the rate for real property.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1) of this subsection does not affect a special rate prevailing in a taxing district or part of a municipal corporation.

section.text: If a special rate of county or municipal corporation property tax is provided by this subtitle, that rate may be applied to the appropriate assessment of property without the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of the county or of the municipal corporation passing a law to set that rate.

subsection.text: In this section, “tax setoff” means:

paragraph.text: the difference between the general county property tax rate and the property tax rate that is set for assessments of property in a municipal corporation; or
a payment to a municipal corporation to aid the municipal corporation in funding services or programs that are similar to county services or programs.

subsection.text: This section applies only in:

paragraph.text: Allegany County;
Anne Arundel County;
Baltimore County;
Frederick County;
Garrett County;
Harford County;
Howard County;
Montgomery County; and
Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: The governing body of the county shall meet and discuss with the governing body of any municipal corporation in the county the county property tax rate to be set for assessments of property in the municipal corporation as provided in this section. After the meeting if it can be demonstrated that a municipal corporation performs services or programs instead of similar county services or programs, the governing body of the county shall grant a tax setoff to the municipal corporation.

Except as provided in subsection (k) of this section, in determining the county property tax rate to be set for assessments of property in a municipal corporation, the governing body of the county shall consider:

paragraph.text: the services and programs that are performed by the municipal corporation instead of similar county services and programs; and
the extent that the similar services and programs are funded by property tax revenues.

subsection.text: The county property tax rate for assessments of property located in a municipal corporation is not required to be:

paragraph.text: the same as the rate for property located in other municipal corporations in the county; or
the same as the rate set in a prior year.

At least 180 days before the date that the annual county budget is required to be approved, any municipal corporation in the county that desires that a tax setoff be provided shall submit to the county a proposal that states the desired level of property tax setoff for the next fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: A request submitted under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be accompanied by:

sub-subparagraph.text: a description of the scope and nature of the services or programs provided by the municipal corporation instead of similar services or programs provided by the county; and
financial records and other documentation regarding municipal revenues and expenditures.

subparagraph.text: The materials submitted under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph shall provide sufficient detail for an assessment of the similar services or programs.

paragraph.text: After receiving a proposal from a municipal corporation requesting a tax setoff under this subsection, the governing body of the county shall promptly submit to the municipal corporation financial records and other documentation regarding county revenues and expenditures.

At least 90 days before the date that the annual county budget is required to be approved, the county and any municipal corporation submitting a tax setoff request under subsection (f) of this section shall designate appropriate policy and fiscal officers or representatives to meet and discuss the nature of the tax setoff request, relevant financial information of the county and municipal corporation, and the scope and nature of services provided by both entities.
A meeting held under paragraph (1) of this subsection may be held by the county representatives jointly with representatives from more than one municipal corporation.

subparagraph.text: The county officers or representatives may request from the municipal corporation officers or representatives additional information that may reasonably be needed to assess the tax setoff.
The municipal corporation officers or representatives shall provide the additional information expeditiously.

paragraph.text: At or before the time the proposed county budget is released to the public, the county commissioners, the county executive of a charter county, or the county council of a charter county without a county executive shall submit a statement of intent to each municipal corporation that has requested a tax setoff.
The statement of intent shall contain:

subparagraph.text: an explanation of the level of the proposed tax setoff;
a description of the information or process used to determine the level of the proposed tax setoff; and

an indication that, before the budget is enacted, appropriate officials or representatives of the municipal corporation are entitled to appear before the county governing body to discuss or contest the level of the proposed tax setoff.

subsection.text: Representatives of each municipal corporation in the county requesting a tax setoff shall be afforded an opportunity to testify before the county governing body during normally scheduled hearings on the county’s proposed budget.
Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections (d), (f), and (g) of this section:

paragraph.text: a county and one or more municipal corporations may enter into an agreement setting different terms or timing for negotiations, calculations, or approval of a tax setoff; and
a county may grant a tax setoff to a municipal corporation that does not make a request in the fashion described in this section.

subsection.text: In Frederick County, for the taxable years that begin July 1, 2011, and July 1, 2012, the governing body of Frederick County shall grant a tax setoff to a municipal corporation in an amount that:

paragraph.text: is no less than the tax setoff granted to that municipal corporation for the preceding taxable year; and
increases by the same percentage by which the county property tax rate exceeds the constant yield tax rate.

subsection.text: In this section, “tax setoff” means:

paragraph.text: the difference between the general county property tax rate and the property tax rate that is set for assessments of property in a municipal corporation; or
a payment to a municipal corporation to aid the municipal corporation in funding services or programs that are similar to county services or programs.

subsection.text: This section applies to any county not listed in § 6-305 of this subtitle.

The governing body of the county shall meet and discuss with the governing body of any municipal corporation in the county the county property tax rate to be set for assessments of property in the municipal corporation as provided in this section. After the meeting if a municipal corporation performs services or programs instead of similar county services or programs, the governing body of the county may grant a tax setoff to the municipal corporation.
In determining the county property tax rate to be set for assessments of property in a municipal corporation, the governing body of the county may consider:

paragraph.text: the services and programs that are performed by the municipal corporation instead of similar county services and programs; and
the extent that the similar services and programs are funded by property tax revenues.

subsection.text: The county property tax rate for assessments of property located in a municipal corporation is not required to be:

paragraph.text: the same as the rate for property located in other municipal corporations in the county; or
the same as the rate set in a prior year.

At least 180 days before the date that the annual county budget is required to be approved, any municipal corporation in the county that desires that a tax setoff be provided shall submit to the county a proposal that states the desired level of property tax setoff for the next fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: A request submitted under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be accompanied by:

sub-subparagraph.text: a description of the scope and nature of the services or programs provided by the municipal corporation instead of similar services or programs provided by the county; and
financial records and other documentation regarding municipal revenues and expenditures.

subparagraph.text: The materials submitted under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph shall provide sufficient detail for an assessment of the similar services or programs.
