sub-subparagraph.text: obtain at least 250,000 square feet of new or expanded premises by purchasing newly constructed premises, constructing new premises, causing new premises to be constructed, or leasing newly constructed premises;

continue to employ at least 2,500 individuals in existing permanent full–time positions paying at least 150% of the federal minimum wage and located at premises in the State where the business entity, along with its affiliates, is primarily engaged in one or more of the industries listed in paragraph (2) of this subsection; and

employ at least 500 individuals in new permanent full–time positions paying at least 150% of the federal minimum wage and located in the new or expanded premises, and, if applicable, in newly renovated premises adjoining or otherwise neighboring the new or expanded premises;

obtain at least 250,000 square feet of new or expanded premises by purchasing newly constructed premises, constructing new premises, causing new premises to be constructed, or leasing newly constructed premises; and

employ at least 1,250 individuals in new permanent full–time positions paying at least 150% of the federal minimum wage and located in the new or expanded premises and, if applicable, in newly renovated premises adjoining or otherwise neighboring the new or expanded premises; or

subparagraph.text: in Montgomery County only:

sub-subparagraph.text: expend at least $150 million to obtain at least 700,000 square feet of new or expanded premises by purchasing newly constructed premises, constructing new premises, causing new premises to be constructed, or leasing newly constructed premises; and

employ a total of at least 1,100 individuals in full–time positions consisting of both full–time positions of indefinite duration and contract positions of definite duration lasting at least 12 months with an unlimited renewal option, and including at least 500 individuals in new permanent full–time positions, with all positions:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: receiving an employer provided subsidized health care benefits package;
paying at least 150% of the federal minimum wage; and
located in the new or expanded premises and, if applicable, in newly renovated premises adjoining or otherwise neighboring the new or expanded premises.

paragraph.text: For a business entity to qualify for an enhanced property tax credit under this subsection, the business entity, along with its affiliates, shall be primarily engaged in one or more of the following at the qualifying premises:

subparagraph.text: manufacturing or mining;
transportation or communications;
agriculture, forestry, or fishing;
research, development, or testing;
biotechnology;
computer programming, data processing, or other computer–related services;
central services as defined in § 6–101 of the Economic Development Article;
the operation of central administrative offices or a company headquarters as defined in § 6–101 of the Economic Development Article;
a public utility;
warehousing; or
business services.

paragraph.text: To qualify for the enhanced property tax credit under this subsection, a business entity shall:

subparagraph.text: within a 6–year period beginning on the notification date, employ individuals in the number of new permanent full–time positions required under paragraph (1) of this subsection;
during the 6–year hiring period, obtain and occupy the new or expanded premises and, if applicable, the newly renovated premises adjoining or otherwise neighboring the new or expanded premises; and
during the 6–year hiring period, comply with all other requirements for the credits described in this subsection and in any applicable local law.

If a business entity meets the requirements of this subsection and subsection (b) of this section and of applicable local law adopted under subsection (b)(1) of this section, for each of the first 24 taxable years after it qualifies for the credit, a property tax credit may be claimed against the county or municipal corporation property taxes that would otherwise be due.
The county or municipal corporation shall compute the amount of the property tax credit granted to equal 58.5% of the amount of property tax imposed on the increase in assessment of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the new or expanded premises;

newly renovated real property improvements adjoining or otherwise neighboring the new or expanded premises, if the renovations are substantial, as defined in legislation enacted by the county or municipal corporation to grant the credits under this subsection; and
the personal property located on the premises described in items 1 and 2 of this subparagraph.

subparagraph.text: The increase in assessment shall be measured from the notification date to the applicable annual assessment date after the county or municipal corporation has certified that the business entity has qualified for the credit.

paragraph.text: On receipt of notification under subsection (b)(7) of this section that a business entity has been certified for an enhanced property tax credit under this subsection, the Department shall compute and certify to the Comptroller or, in the case of the insurance premiums tax, the Maryland Insurance Commissioner the amount of the State tax credit authorized under this subsection that may be claimed by the business entity or any of its affiliates against the individual or corporate income tax, insurance premiums tax, or financial institution franchise tax that would otherwise be due to equal 31.5% of the amount of property tax imposed on the increase in assessment of the real and personal property described in paragraph (4)(ii) of this subsection for each of the first 24 taxable years for which the credit is allowed.
If a business entity or any of its affiliates claim the enhanced tax credits under this subsection for a certain premises, they may not claim the tax credits under subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: The same State tax credit cannot be applied more than once against different taxes by the same taxpayer.

If the State tax credit allowed under this section in any taxable year exceeds the total tax otherwise payable by the business entity for that taxable year, a business entity or its affiliates may apply the excess as a credit for succeeding taxable years until the earlier of:

paragraph.text: the full amount of the excess is used; or
the expiration of the 5th taxable year after the taxable year in which the State tax credit is claimed.

subsection.text: The Maryland Insurance Commissioner shall adopt regulations to provide for the computation, carryover, and recapture of the State tax credit under § 6–116 of the Insurance Article.
The Department shall adopt regulations to provide for the computation, carryover, and recapture of the State tax credit under § 8–217 of the Tax – General Article.
The Comptroller shall adopt regulations to provide for the computation, carryover, and recapture of the State tax credit under § 10–704.8 of the Tax – General Article.

The lessor of real property eligible for property tax credits under this section shall reduce by the amount of the property tax credits computed under this section the amount of taxes for which the eligible business entity is contractually liable under the lease agreement.
The governing body of the county or municipal corporation shall provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the specific requirements for eligibility for a tax credit authorized under this section;
any additional limitations on eligibility for the credit;
the information to be supplied by the business entity to a county or municipal corporation and the Comptroller to verify that the business entity is not subject to subsection (l) of this section; and
any other provision appropriate to implement the credit.

subsection.text: All credits claimed under this section for a taxable year shall be recaptured if, during the 3 taxable years succeeding the taxable year in which a credit was claimed:

paragraph.text: the employment level or square footage of a business entity at the premises falls below the applicable thresholds required to qualify for the property tax credit under subsection (c) of this section; or

for the enhanced property tax credit, the employment level or square footage of a business entity, together with its affiliates, at the premises falls below the applicable thresholds required to qualify for the enhanced property tax credit under subsection (d) of this section.

subsection.text: On October 1 of each year, each county and municipal corporation that has granted tax credits under this section shall report to the Department, the Department of Business and Economic Development, and the Comptroller:

paragraph.text: the amount of each credit granted for that year; and
whether the business entity is in compliance with the requirements for the tax credit.

After a business entity has complied with all the requirements provided in this section and in any applicable local law for a particular tax credit, the business entity shall be entitled to claim the credits for the term provided in this section.

No abrogation of this law or law hereinafter enacted that eliminates or reduces the tax credits available under this section shall apply to any business entity or affiliate of a business entity that qualified for the tax credits before the effective date of such law or abrogation.

subsection.text: In this section, “foreign trade zone” means a foreign trade zone or subzone established under federal law.

The governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal property tax imposed on personal property, other than operating personal property of a public utility, if the personal property is located in a foreign trade zone that is within that county or municipal corporation.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on improvements to real property if there is installed in the improvements a complete automatic fire protection sprinkler system, installed in accordance with accepted codes and standards established by the Maryland State Fire Prevention Commission.
A county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount of a property tax credit under this section;
the duration of a property tax credit under this section;
the criteria and qualifications necessary to receive the credit;
the application of a property tax credit under this section to existing automatic fire protection sprinkler systems; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this section.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on property owned by the Audubon Naturalist Society of the Central Atlantic States, Inc. that is used solely for:

paragraph.text: the environmental education of the public; or
the maintenance of:

subparagraph.text: a natural area for public use; or
a sanctuary for wildlife.

subsection.text: If a taxing jurisdiction grants a property tax credit under this section, the credit shall also apply to the State property tax in that jurisdiction in the same percentage and for the same duration as provided for the property tax of the taxing jurisdiction.

The governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property containing a vacant or underutilized commercial building that:

paragraph.text: was built primarily for office, industrial, or other commercial purposes;
was last used for office, industrial, or other commercial purposes; and
is renovated for use primarily as housing.

subsection.text: The governing body of a county or municipal corporation may establish conditions for the granting of a property tax credit under paragraph (1) of this subsection, including:

paragraph.text: eligibility criteria;
application procedures; and
provisions for a payment in lieu of taxes to the county or municipal corporation by the recipient of the tax credit.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on athletic fields that are used exclusively for amateur sports.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this section; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this section.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is rehabilitated under regulations adopted by the governing body.

paragraph.text: A property tax credit granted under this section may not extend beyond the first 10 years after the rehabilitation is completed.

The amount of a tax credit granted under this section may not exceed the property tax increase attributable to the increase in the assessment of the real property over the assessment before the real property is rehabilitated.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may, by law:

paragraph.text: subject to the limitations under subsection (b) of this section, provide for the amount and duration of a property tax credit granted under this section;
limit eligibility for the credit to real property used for specified purposes or to real property located in designated revitalization areas; or
otherwise provide additional requirements for eligibility or additional limitations for a tax credit granted under this section.

section.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on personal property that is used in practicing dentistry in a geographic area of the State that has been designated by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene as being underserved by dentists.

subsection.text: In this section, “community association” means:

paragraph.text: a neighborhood organization that:

subparagraph.text: is comprised of city blocks of at least 25 households or 25% of the households of a local neighborhood consisting of 40 or more individual households, whichever is less, as defined by specific geographic boundaries in the bylaws or charter of the association;
is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code;
requires as a condition of membership, the voluntary payment of monetary dues or membership fees at least annually; and
is organized and operated for one or more of the following purposes:

sub-subparagraph.text: relief of neighborhood tensions;
prevention of community deterioration;
provision of relief to the poor, underprivileged, or distressed;
preservation of historic areas;
community revitalization; or
promotion of the common good and social welfare of the people of the community; or

paragraph.text: an umbrella organization that:

subparagraph.text: consists of coalitions of several neighborhood organizations as described in paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
addresses issues that affect broad areas of the county or municipal corporation where the umbrella organization is located.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this subsection against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on personal property that is owned by a community association for a taxable year, if:

paragraph.text: the community association was in existence as of the first day of the taxable year for which the credit under this section is to be allowed;
the community association is in good standing, if it is organized as a Maryland corporation; and
the personal property is valued at $8,000 or less.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Existing electricity generation facility” means an electricity generation facility that:

subparagraph.text: exists in a county before June 1, 2001; and
receives approval for a modification under § 7–205 of the Public Utilities Article.

paragraph.text: “Machinery and equipment of a new electricity generation facility” means machinery and equipment used in the generation of electricity at a new electricity generation facility.

“Machinery and equipment of an existing electricity generation facility” means machinery and equipment used in the generation of electricity and added as part of an expansion of an existing electricity generation facility for the purpose of increasing electricity production at the existing electricity generation facility.
“New electricity generation facility” means an electricity generation facility that:

subparagraph.text: locates in a county on or after June 1, 2001; and
receives a certificate of public convenience and necessity under § 7–207 of the Public Utilities Article.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, to the extent that a county grants a personal property tax credit for the machinery and equipment of a new electricity generation facility or the machinery and equipment of an existing electricity generation facility, the machinery and equipment may not be treated as taxable personal property for the purpose of computing any payments of State aid to education under § 5–202 of the Education Article or other payments of State aid to counties or municipal corporations that by law are based on the assessment of property.

Subsection (b) of this section does not apply to any personal property unless the county submits to the Department, on or before October 31 of the taxable year for which the tax credit for the property is granted, the information required under § 9–201(b) of this subtitle regarding the tax credit.
In this section, “arts and entertainment district”, “arts and entertainment enterprise”, and “qualifying residing artist” have the meanings stated in § 4–701 of the Economic Development Article.

The governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on a manufacturing, commercial, or industrial building that:

paragraph.text: is located in an arts and entertainment district; and
is wholly or partially constructed or renovated to be capable for use by a qualifying residing artist or an arts and entertainment enterprise.

subsection.text: A tax credit granted under this section may not be granted for more than 10 years.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on personal property, other than operating personal property of a public utility, of a business that provides computers to its employees for their use at home.
A county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount of a property tax credit under this section;
the duration of a property tax credit under this section;
the criteria and qualifications necessary to receive the credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this section.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, in this section, “high performance building” means a building that:

subparagraph.text: achieves at least a silver rating according to the U.S. Green Building Council’s LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) green building rating system as adopted by the Maryland Green Building Council;
is a residential building that achieves at least a silver rating according to the International Code Council’s 700 National Green Building Standards;
achieves at least a comparable rating according to any other appropriate rating system; or
meets comparable green building guidelines or standards approved by the State.

paragraph.text: For purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection, under LEED Credit MR7 or a similar criterion in a comparable rating system, credit may be awarded for the use of wood–based materials derived from all credible sources, including the Sustainable Forestry Initiative Program, the Canadian Standards Association, the American Tree Farm System, and other credible certified sources programs.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on a high performance building.
A county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount of a property tax credit under this section;
the duration of a property tax credit under this section;
the criteria and qualifications necessary to receive the credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this section.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant a tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property if:

paragraph.text: the homeowner is otherwise eligible for the credit allowed under § 9-105 of this title;

subparagraph.text: the dwelling is:

sub-subparagraph.text: damaged or destroyed due to a natural disaster; and
subsequently repaired or reconstructed;

subparagraph.text: the dwelling is revalued after the dwelling is repaired or reconstructed; and
as a result of the revaluation, the assessment of the dwelling exceeds the last assessment of the dwelling; and

paragraph.text: the homeowner claiming the credit had a legal interest in the dwelling at the time the dwelling was damaged or destroyed as described under item (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A homeowner may receive a tax credit under this section only if the homeowner qualified and received a tax credit under § 9-109 of this title and is no longer receiving a tax credit under § 9-109 of this title.

The amount of the property tax credit allowed under this section shall equal 50% of the property tax attributable to an increase in the assessment of the dwelling on revaluation under § 8-104(c)(1)(iii) of this article, including improvements, over the last assessment of the dwelling before the natural disaster, less the amount of any assessment on which a property tax credit under § 9-105 of this title has been authorized.
A credit under this section may not be granted for more than 3 years.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may:

paragraph.text: establish procedures or requirements for the application, review, and approval of tax credits under this section;
establish additional eligibility criteria such as age, income level, or assessment value; and
notify the Department of any credits that have been granted under this section.

subsection.text: The credit under this section may not be claimed for a dwelling for which repair or reconstruction is completed before September 18, 2003.

The governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation or the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on a nonprofit swim club that uses its facility exclusively to provide a recreational outlet for a local community.
The governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation or the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the administration of requests for the tax credit under this section; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the tax credit under this section.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is owned by and used as the principal residence of an individual who is at least 65 years old and of limited income.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the property tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this section.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Acquired dwelling” means a dwelling:

subparagraph.text: that was owned by a qualified displaced homeowner;

that by negotiation or condemnation was acquired from the qualified displaced homeowner for public use by the State or a political subdivision or instrumentality of the State, where the acquiring agency had the power to acquire the dwelling for public use by condemnation; and
for which the qualified displaced homeowner was eligible for a credit under § 9–105 of this title for the taxable year in which the dwelling was acquired for public use.

paragraph.text: “Acquisition year” means the taxable year in which an acquired dwelling was acquired for public use by the State or a political subdivision or instrumentality of the State.
“Dwelling” has the meaning stated in § 9–105 of this title.
“Qualified displaced homeowner” means a property owner who:

subparagraph.text: qualified for a credit under § 9–105 of this title for an acquired dwelling for the acquisition year; and
did not receive compensation for increased property taxes resulting from the loss of the credit under § 9–105 of this title.

paragraph.text: “Replacement dwelling” means a dwelling that is purchased by a qualified displaced homeowner by the end of the taxable year following the acquisition year.
“Taxable assessment” has the meaning stated in § 9–105 of this title.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit as provided in this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on a replacement dwelling.

paragraph.text: The property tax credit under this section may not exceed 100% of the county or municipal corporation property tax attributable to the eligible homestead assessment of the acquired dwelling, as determined under paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection.

The county or municipal corporation property tax attributable to the eligible homestead assessment of the acquired dwelling is the product of multiplying the applicable county or municipal corporation tax rate for the current year times the eligible homestead assessment of the acquired dwelling, as determined under paragraph (3) of this subsection.

For purposes of paragraph (2) of this subsection, and subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, the eligible homestead assessment of the acquired dwelling is the amount by which the acquisition year assessment of the acquired dwelling exceeds the product of multiplying the prior year’s taxable assessment of the acquired dwelling times:

subparagraph.text: for purposes of the county or municipal corporation property tax where the replacement dwelling and the acquired dwelling are located in the same county or the same municipal corporation, the homestead credit percentage applicable to the county property tax or municipal corporation property tax for the acquisition year; and
for purposes of the county or municipal corporation property tax where the replacement dwelling and the acquired dwelling are not located in the same county or the same municipal corporation, 110%.

paragraph.text: The eligible homestead assessment determined under paragraph (3) of this subsection shall be reduced, but not below zero, by the amount, if any, by which the acquisition year assessment of the acquired dwelling exceeds the assessment of the replacement dwelling for the first taxable year for which the credit under this section is allowed.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the property tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “business incubator” means a program in which units of space are leased by multiple early–stage businesses that share physical common space, administrative services and equipment, business management training, mentoring, and technical support.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal property tax imposed on property that is used as a business incubator if the State, a county, a municipal corporation, an organization exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, a public institution of higher education, or an agency or instrumentality of the State, a county, a municipal corporation, or a public institution of higher education:

paragraph.text: owns, controls, or leases the space that is used as a business incubator;
provides at least 50% of the total funding received by the business incubator from all sources, not including rents received from incubator tenant firms; or
is represented on the governance board that authorizes the annual budget of the business incubator.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the property tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “family assistance dwelling” means a house, and the lot or curtilage on which the house is erected, if the house:

paragraph.text: is not a vacation home;
is not the residence of the homeowner but treated as used by the homeowner for personal purposes within the meaning of § 280A(d) of the Internal Revenue Code; and
is the only residence of an individual who:

subparagraph.text: is the brother, sister, half–brother, half–sister, spouse, parent, step–parent, grandparent, child, step–child, adopted child, or grandchild of the homeowner;
makes rental payments to the homeowner that are less than 90% of a fair rental price paid for a similar dwelling in the same area; and
is entitled to low income assistance benefits under a federal or State program.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on a family assistance dwelling.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this section.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Commercial fish operation” means any activity for which a person is required to possess a tidal fish license under § 4–701 of the Natural Resources Article.
“Commercial fish operation” includes any activity for which a person is required to be licensed as a seafood dealer under § 4–701 of the Natural Resources Article.

paragraph.text: “Commercial fishing vessel” means a vessel that is:

subparagraph.text: owned or leased by a person possessing a tidal fish license under § 4–701 of the Natural Resources Article; and
used in a commercial fish operation.

paragraph.text: “Commercial marina” means a marina that leases at least 20% of its slips to commercial fishing vessels.
“Commercial marine repair facility” means a marine repair facility that derives at least 20% of its gross receipts from charges for the repair and maintenance of commercial fishing vessels.

subparagraph.text: “Commercial waterfront property” means real property that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is adjacent to the tidal waters of the State;
is used primarily for a commercial fish operation or as a commercial marina or commercial marine repair facility; and
for the most recent 3–year period, has produced an average annual gross income of at least $1,000.

subparagraph.text: “Commercial waterfront property” includes land that is adjacent to or under improvements used primarily for a commercial fish operation or as a commercial marina or commercial marine repair facility.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on commercial waterfront property.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “accessibility feature” means:

paragraph.text: a no–step entrance allowing access into a residence;
interior passage doors providing at least a 32–inch–wide clear opening;
grab bars around a toilet, tub, or shower installed to support at least 250 pounds;
light switches, outlets, and thermostats placed in wheelchair–accessible locations;
lever handles on doors; and
universal design features or any accessibility enhancing design feature prescribed by the Department of Housing and Community Development under § 12–202 of the Public Safety Article.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on residential real property equipped with an accessibility feature.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this section.

subsection.text: In this section:

paragraph.text: “marine trade waterfront property” means real property that:

subparagraph.text: is adjacent to the tidal waters of the State;
is used primarily for an activity or business that requires direct access to, or location in, marine waters due to the nature of the activity or business; and
for the most recent 3–year period, has produced an average annual gross income of at least $1,000; and

paragraph.text: “marine trade waterfront property” includes:

subparagraph.text: marinas, boat ramps, boat hauling and repair facilities, fishing facilities, and any other boating facilities; and
land that is adjacent to or under improvements used primarily for an activity or business that requires access to, or location in, marine waters due to the nature of the activity or business.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on marine trade waterfront property.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this section.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax that is imposed on real property that is:

paragraph.text: owned by Habitat for Humanity with the intention of relinquishing ownership in the near future;
used for the purposes of development, rehabilitation, and transfer to a private owner; and
not occupied by administrative or warehouse buildings owned by Habitat for Humanity.

subsection.text: If the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation grants a property tax credit under this section, Habitat for Humanity shall submit an annual written report to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation granting the tax credit documenting:

paragraph.text: all of Habitat for Humanity’s real property holdings in the jurisdiction granting the tax credit; and
all transactions involving Habitat for Humanity’s real property holdings in the jurisdiction granting the tax credit.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may, by law:

paragraph.text: set the amount, terms, scope, and duration of a credit granted under subsection (a) of this section; and
adopt any other provision necessary to administer a credit granted under subsection (a) of this section.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Urban agricultural property” means real property that is:

subparagraph.text: at least one–eighth of an acre and not more than 2 acres;
located in a priority funding area, as defined in § 5–7B–02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
used exclusively for urban agricultural purposes.

paragraph.text: “Urban agricultural purposes” means:

subparagraph.text: crop production activities, including the use of mulch or cover crops to ensure maximum productivity and minimize runoff and weed production;
environmental mitigation activities, including stormwater abatement and groundwater protection;
community development activities, including recreational activities, food donations, and food preparation and canning classes;
economic development activities, including employment and training opportunities, and direct sales to restaurants and institutions; and
temporary produce stands used for the sale of produce raised on the premises.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on urban agricultural property.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a tax credit under this section shall be granted for 5 years.

subparagraph.text: If the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation grants a tax credit under this section, the jurisdiction granting a tax credit shall evaluate the effectiveness of the credit after 3 years.

If the jurisdiction granting the tax credit determines that the tax credit is ineffective in promoting urban agricultural purposes, the jurisdiction granting a tax credit may terminate the tax credit.
The jurisdiction granting a tax credit under this section may extend the tax credit for an additional 5 years.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount of the tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this section.

subsection.text: At any time during the period for which a property tax credit under this section is granted for urban agricultural property, if the property ceases to be used for urban agricultural purposes, the owner of the property shall be liable for all property taxes that would have been imposed if a property tax credit for urban agricultural property had not been granted.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Grocery store” means an entity:

subparagraph.text: whose primary business is selling food at retail to the general public for off–premises consumption; and
at least 20% of the gross receipts of which are derived from the retail sale of fresh produce, meats, and dairy products.

paragraph.text: “Low–income area” means an area designated, by law, by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation as a low–income area for purposes of a tax credit under this section.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is used for a grocery store located in a low–income area.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this section;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this section;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this section.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on owner–occupied, residential real property that is purchased from July 1, 2012, through June 30, 2018, and is located in a neighborhood conservation area established or renewed by application to the Department of Housing and Community Development based on the criteria specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The Department of Housing and Community Development shall adopt regulations that establish application procedures for the designation of a neighborhood conservation area based on:

subparagraph.text: the concentration of foreclosure activity;
the concentration of blighted or vacant properties; and
the location within a priority funding area, with preference given to sustainable communities under § 6–201 of the Housing and Community Development Article.

subsection.text: In order to qualify for the credit under this section:

paragraph.text: for the 12–month period immediately prior to purchasing the property, the individual’s principal residence may not have been located in a neighborhood conservation area designated under this section unless the individual was not an owner of the property that was the individual’s principal residence; and

the residential real property must have been purchased in conformance with the eligibility requirements for the credit under this section as established by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of the county or municipal corporation.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation shall provide, by law, for:

paragraph.text: the amount of the property tax credit authorized under this section for each taxable year after the purchase of the residential real property;
the designation of certain geographic areas as neighborhood conservation areas for purposes of the tax credit authorized under this section;
any additional limitations on eligibility for the credit under this section; and
any other provision necessary to implement the credit under this section.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation shall provide, on an annual basis to those individuals qualifying for the property tax credit under this section, a statement certifying qualification for the tax credit and the amount of the tax credit being granted.
The statement may be provided on or with the annual property tax bill or in another manner as chosen by the local government.

subsection.text: On or before January 1, of the calendar year following the year in which the neighborhood conservation tax credit is initiated, and each January 1 thereafter, a county or municipal corporation that grants a tax credit under this section shall submit a report, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, to the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee that describes:

paragraph.text: the tax credit program;
the designated neighborhood conservation areas;
the number of residential properties within neighborhood conservation areas that qualify for the tax credit under this section; and
the economic impact of the tax credits granted under this section on the neighborhood conservation areas.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise specifically provided, the provisions of this section apply to property tax credits granted under this subtitle.
A property tax credit granted under this subtitle shall be granted against 100% of all property tax or special district charges that otherwise would be due.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the appropriate governing body may adopt regulations necessary to carry out the property tax credit provisions of this subtitle.

When a tax bill is sent to a taxpayer who is entitled to a property tax credit under this subtitle, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the appropriate governing body shall give notice of each property tax credit under this subtitle that the taxpayer is entitled to.

paragraph.text: To receive a property tax credit under this subtitle, a taxpayer shall apply for the property tax credit.

Except as provided under § 9-312 of this subtitle for Frederick County, if a taxpayer fails to apply for a property tax credit under this subtitle on or before October 1 of each taxable year, the property tax credit may not be granted.
A taxpayer shall state under oath that the facts in the application are true.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or each governing body that grants a property tax credit under this subtitle shall designate the administrative unit or official to administer each tax credit that it grants under this subtitle.

Annually on or before December 31, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or each governing body that grants a property tax credit under this subtitle shall submit to the Department on the form that the Department provides:

subparagraph.text: the total value of all property tax credits granted by the governing body under this subtitle;
an itemized list of the property tax credits granted for real property; and
an itemized list of the property tax credits granted for personal property.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or each governing body that grants a property tax credit under this subtitle shall:

subparagraph.text: in the same manner as the assessment roll, make available for public inspection bound copies of the forms required by paragraph (2) of this subsection; and
identify clearly on the tax roll the properties that are granted a property tax credit under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The governing body of Allegany County and of a municipal corporation in Allegany County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county and municipal corporation property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: personal property that is owned by a nonprofit television broadcast translator station that is supported principally by public subscription; and
property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the South Cumberland Business and Civic Association, Incorporated; and
known as the South Cumberland Civic Center.

subsection.text: The governing body of Allegany County or of a municipal corporation in Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: property that is owned by the Upper Potomac Jaycees, Incorporated;
property that is owned by the Allegany Beagle Club, Incorporated;
property that is:

subparagraph.text: leased by Frostburg Community Hospital, Inc.; and
used for hospital purposes;

paragraph.text: property that is owned by the Western Maryland Scenic Railroad;
property that is owned by the Frostburg Lions Club;
property that is owned by the Cumberland/Allegany County Industrial Foundation, Inc.;
property that is owned by the La Vale Lions Club Foundation, Inc.;
property that is owned by the Carver Community Center, Inc.;
property that is owned by the Cumberland Cultural Foundation and is known as the Gilchrist Museum;
property that is owned by the Allegany County Agricultural Expo, Inc.; and
property that is owned by the Allegany County Building Trades Education Foundation, Inc.
The governing body of Allegany County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned directly or indirectly by a bona fide labor union or a corporation whose capital stock is owned only by a bona fide labor union;
used only for the mutual benefit of the members of the bona fide labor union; and
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, not used for profit;

subparagraph.text: real property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by a religious organization;
leased to the La Vale Athletic Association;
located in La Vale; and
used only to conduct athletic and recreational programs for youth; and

subparagraph.text: real property on which improvements are made to a structure that the governing body of Allegany County has certified to be historically or architecturally significant.

paragraph.text: Any property under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection that is commercially rented is taxable to the extent of the commercial use of the property.
A property tax credit granted under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: the following percentage of the increase that is due to the improvement:

sub-subparagraph.text: 100% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 1st and 2nd taxable years that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax;
80% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 3rd taxable year that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax;
60% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 4th taxable year that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax; and
40% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 5th taxable year that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax; and

subparagraph.text: ended after the 5th taxable year that the improved structure is subject to county property tax.

subsection.text: The governing body of Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on real property that is:

paragraph.text: owned by the Greater Cumberland Chamber of Commerce;
known as the Bell Tower Building; and
located in Cumberland, Maryland.

subsection.text: The governing body of Allegany County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county and special district property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: property that is owned by the Cresaptown Civic Improvement Association, Incorporated; and
property that is owned by the Potomac Park Citizens Committee, Incorporated.

subsection.text: The governing body of Allegany County or of the City of Cumberland may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county and municipal corporation tax imposed on property that is owned by the Cumberland Outdoor Club, Incorporated.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Allegany County or of the City of Cumberland may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county and municipal corporation tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: property that is rehabilitated under regulations adopted by the governing body; or
property that is new construction under regulations adopted by the governing body.

paragraph.text: A property tax credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection may not extend beyond the first 10 years after the rehabilitation or new construction is completed.

The amount of a tax credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection may not exceed the amount of the initial valuation of the rehabilitation to the property or the new construction and the resulting phase-in of the valuation.

subsection.text: The governing body of Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county and special district property tax imposed on property that is owned by the Western Maryland Street Rod Association, Incorporated.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Allegany County may grant a county property tax credit or exemption for machinery and equipment used in manufacturing, assembling, processing, or refining products for sale or in the generation of electricity and may define, fix, or limit the amount, terms, scope, and duration of any credit or exemption provided for or affirmed under this subsection.

To the extent that a tax credit or exemption is granted under this subsection for machinery and equipment used in manufacturing, assembling, processing, or refining products for sale, the property may not be treated as taxable personal property for the purpose of computing any payments of State aid to education under § 5-202 of the Education Article or other payments of State aid to counties or municipal corporations that by law are based on the assessment of property.

To the extent that a tax credit or exemption is granted under this subsection for machinery and equipment that is used in the generation of electricity for a facility that started generating electricity prior to June 1, 2000, the property may not be treated as taxable personal property for the purpose of computing any payments of State aid to education under § 5-202 of the Education Article or other payments of State aid to counties or municipal corporations that by law are based on the assessment of property.

Paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection do not apply to any personal property unless Allegany County submits to the Department, on or before October 31 of the taxable year for which the tax credit or exemption for the property is granted, the information required under § 9-201(b) of this title regarding the tax credit or exemption.

To encourage the location and development of business operations and expansion of the employment base in Allegany County, the governing body of Allegany County and of a municipal corporation in Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county and municipal corporation property tax imposed on any property within:

subparagraph.text: the area known as the Riverside Industrial Park;
a commercial or industrial park owned, managed, or operated by the Allegany County Commissioners; or
a public industrial park owned, managed, or operated by an organization described in § 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code.

paragraph.text: In authorizing a credit under paragraph (1)(ii) or (iii) of this subsection, the governing body of the county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the credit; and
any other provision necessary to administer the credit.

paragraph.text: A tax credit granted under this subsection may not be granted for more than 10 years.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the governing body of Allegany County or of a municipal corporation in Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on property that is subdivided into five or more lots for purposes of future residential development.

subparagraph.text: A property tax credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall equal 100% of the tax imposed on the increase in the assessment of the real property when the property is first revalued following the subdivision of the property.
A property tax credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection does not apply to a subdivided lot that has been transferred to a new owner after the property was subdivided.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Allegany County or of a municipal corporation in Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on any property that:

subparagraph.text: is owned by Western Maryland Health System Corporation;
was formerly designated and operated as Western Maryland Health System Braddock Hospital; and
is vacant as a result of hospital consolidation and relocation approved by the Maryland Health Care Commission.

paragraph.text: To encourage the location and development of business operations and expansion of the employment base in Allegany County, the governing body of Allegany County or of a municipal corporation in Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on any property that:

subparagraph.text: was formerly owned by Western Maryland Health System Corporation;
was formerly designated and operated as Western Maryland Health System Braddock Hospital;
was formerly vacant as a result of hospital consolidation and relocation approved by the Maryland Health Care Commission; and
is owned, managed, or operated by an organization described in § 501(c)(3) or § 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code.

paragraph.text: In authorizing a credit under paragraph (1) or (2) of this subsection, the governing body of the county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the credit;
eligibility criteria for the credit;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the credit; and
any other provision necessary to administer the credit.

paragraph.text: A tax credit granted under this subsection may not be granted for more than 10 years.

To encourage the location and development of business operations and expansion of the employment base in Allegany County, the governing body of Allegany County or of a municipal corporation in Allegany County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on any property within the area known as the Memorial Hilltop Centre.
In authorizing a credit under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the governing body of the county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the credit;
eligibility criteria for the credit;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the credit; and
any other provision necessary to administer the credit.

paragraph.text: A tax credit granted under this subsection may not be granted for more than 10 years.

subsection.text: The governing body of Anne Arundel County and of a municipal corporation in Anne Arundel County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county and municipal corporation property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the United States Naval Academy Alumni Association, Incorporated;
located at the corner of College Avenue and King George Street in Annapolis, Maryland; and
known as Ogle Hall;

paragraph.text: property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Naval Academy Athletic Association; and
used for athletic events and purposes;

paragraph.text: real property that is owned by the Three Rivers Sportsmen, Incorporated; and
property that is owned by the Maryland Ornithological Society, Incorporated.

The governing body of Anne Arundel County or of a municipal corporation in Anne Arundel County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation tax imposed on real property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by a nonprofit community civic association or corporation; and
dedicated by plat or deed restriction to the use of the lot owners in the community, if the use is not contingent on the payment of:

sub-subparagraph.text: dues to the association or corporation, unless the dues are used only to improve or maintain the property of the community; or
compensation for admission to or use of the property, unless the compensation is used only to improve or maintain the property of the community.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Anne Arundel County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county tax imposed on real property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Village Commons Community Center, Incorporated; or
leased by Anne Arundel Community College at Arundel Mills.

The governing body of Anne Arundel County or of a municipal corporation in Anne Arundel County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation tax imposed on real property that is owned by Arundel Habitat for Humanity, Inc., and is located at 8101 Fort Smallwood Road, Baltimore, Maryland or 8104 Parkway Drive, Baltimore, Maryland.
The governing body of Anne Arundel County or of a municipal corporation in Anne Arundel County may provide, by law, for:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount, terms, scope, and duration of the credit granted under this paragraph; and
any other provision necessary to administer the credit granted under this paragraph.

subparagraph.text: The governing body of Anne Arundel County or of a municipal corporation in Anne Arundel County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: leased to a public charter school, as defined in § 9–102 of the Education Article; and
used exclusively for primary or secondary educational purposes.

subparagraph.text: The governing body of Anne Arundel County or of a municipal corporation in Anne Arundel County may provide, by law, for:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount and duration of the tax credit under this paragraph;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this paragraph, including a requirement that the tax credit benefit the public charter school;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this paragraph.

subsection.text: The governing body of Anne Arundel County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against county property tax imposed on real property that is owned by the Davidsonville Ruritan Foundation, Incorporated.

The governing body of Anne Arundel County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county tax imposed on real property that is subject to the State’s or county’s agricultural land preservation program.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on real property that:

subparagraph.text: is subject to a perpetual conservation easement donated to the Maryland Environmental Trust on or before June 30, 1986; and
is not eligible for a credit under § 9-107 of this title.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount and duration of the property tax credit under this section; and
any other provisions necessary to carry out the property tax credit under this section.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: real property that is leased, occupied, and used only by the Baltimore Association for Retarded Citizens, Incorporated;
personal property that is owned by the Northwest Family Sport Center, Inc.; and
property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the South Baltimore Little League;
located at 1101 E. Fort Avenue, Baltimore, Maryland; and
used for amateur sports.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “vacant dwelling” means residential real property that:

subparagraph.text: contains no more than four dwelling units; and

sub-subparagraph.text: has been cited as vacant and abandoned on a housing or building violation notice for 1 year; or
has been owned by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City for 1 year and is in need of substantial repair to comply with applicable city codes.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this subsection against the county property tax imposed on real property that is owned by qualifying owners of vacant dwellings.

A property tax credit granted under this subsection may not exceed the amount of county property tax imposed on the increased value of the residential real property that is due to the improvements made to the property immediately before the occupancy permit was issued, multiplied by:

subparagraph.text: 100% for the first taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
80% for the second taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
60% for the third taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
40% for the fourth taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
20% for the fifth taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.

paragraph.text: Owners of vacant dwellings may qualify for the tax credit authorized by this subsection by:

subparagraph.text: substantially rehabilitating the vacant dwelling in compliance with the code and laws applied to dwellings;
occupying the dwelling after rehabilitation as their principal residence; and
satisfying other requirements as may be provided by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide for procedures necessary and appropriate for the submission of an application for and the granting of a property tax credit under this subsection.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.

sub-subparagraph.text: “Newly constructed dwelling” means residential real property that has not been previously occupied since its construction and for which the building permit for construction was issued on or after October 1, 1994.

“Newly constructed dwelling” includes a “vacant dwelling” as defined in subsection (c)(1) of this section that has been rehabilitated in compliance with applicable local laws and regulations and has not been previously occupied since the rehabilitation.

subparagraph.text: “Owner” means “homeowner” as defined in § 9–105 of this title.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this subsection against the county property tax imposed on newly constructed dwellings that are owned by qualifying owners.

A property tax credit granted under this subsection may not exceed the amount of county property tax imposed on the real property, less the amount of any other credit applicable in that year, multiplied by:

subparagraph.text: 50% for the first taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
40% for the second taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
30% for the third taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
20% for the fourth taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
10% for the fifth taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding the credit amount calculated under paragraph (3) of this subsection, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may establish, by law, maximum limits on the cumulative property tax credit allowed under this subsection or on the amount of the credit allowed for any year.
Owners of newly constructed dwellings may qualify for the tax credit authorized by this subsection by:

subparagraph.text: purchasing a newly constructed dwelling;
occupying the newly constructed dwelling as their principal residence;
filing a State income tax return during the period of the tax credit as a resident of Baltimore City; and
satisfying other requirements as may be provided by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide, by law, for two application periods during which owners can apply for the property tax credit under this subsection, one that is based on the purchase date of the dwelling and one that is based on the date of the assessment notice.

sub-subparagraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide, by law, for a one–time amnesty period for owners who were previously denied the tax credit for failing to meet the application deadline.
The amnesty period shall begin at the time the tax credit is reauthorized by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City and shall end 60 days thereafter.
Only owners who were eligible for the tax credit on or after January 1, 2005, may be eligible to apply for the credit during the amnesty period.
If granted, the tax credit shall be applied against the owner’s property taxes as long as the owner remains the owner–occupant of the dwelling for which the credit is received.

subparagraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City shall provide for any procedures necessary and appropriate for implementing the application and amnesty periods.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide for additional procedures necessary and appropriate for the submission of an application for and the granting of a property tax credit under this subsection, including procedures for granting partial credits for eligibility for less than a full taxable year.

The estimated amount of all tax credits received by owners under this subsection in any fiscal year shall be reported by the Director of Finance of Baltimore City as a “tax expenditure” for that fiscal year and shall be included in the publication of the City’s budget for any subsequent fiscal year with the estimated or actual City property tax revenue for the applicable fiscal year.

subparagraph.text: After June 30, 2014, additional owners of newly constructed dwellings may not be granted a credit under this subsection.

This paragraph does not apply to an owner’s continuing receipt of a credit as allowed in paragraph (3) of this subsection, with respect to a property for which a tax credit under this subsection was received for a taxable year ending on or before June 30, 2014.
In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Dwelling” has the meaning stated in § 9-105(a)(2) of this title.
“Homeowner” has the meaning stated in § 9-105(a)(3) of this title.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on a dwelling that:

subparagraph.text: is owned by a homeowner;
has been substantially improved since the last reassessment; and
is reassessed at a higher value.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, a tax credit under this section shall equal the amount of county property tax imposed on the increased value of the dwelling that is due to the improvements made to the property, multiplied by:

subparagraph.text: 100% for the first taxable year following the first reassessment after the improvements are made;
80% for the second taxable year following the first reassessment after the improvements are made;
60% for the third taxable year following the first reassessment after the improvements are made;
40% for the fourth taxable year following the first reassessment after the improvements are made;
20% for the fifth taxable year following the first reassessment after the improvements are made; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.
To continue eligibility for a tax credit under this subsection, a dwelling must remain in compliance with the local housing code.

If a dwelling owned by a person who has received a tax credit under this subsection is found to be in violation of the local housing code, the property owner is not eligible for any further tax credit under this subsection until the dwelling is determined again to be in compliance with the local housing code.
A dwelling that is again brought into compliance is eligible for a tax credit at the rate it would have been eligible before the violation of the local housing code.

paragraph.text: If a dwelling that is eligible for a tax credit under this subsection is transferred, the grantee is eligible for the balance of the property tax credits under this subsection in the same manner and under the same conditions as the grantor of the property.
The property tax credit may not apply to the value of the improvements to the dwelling that exceed $100,000.

To receive the tax credit under this subsection, the homeowner shall have the burden of showing that the increase in assessment is due to the value of the improvements to the dwelling that were made since the last assessment of the dwelling.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Market-rate rental housing project” means a multifamily dwelling containing five or more units in which none of the units are subject to government restrictions on the amount of rent charged or the income level of the tenant.
“Newly constructed” means that an occupancy permit is issued on or after October 1, 1995.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this subsection against the county property tax imposed on newly constructed market-rate rental housing projects.

A property tax credit granted under this subsection may not exceed the amount of county property tax imposed on the real property, less the amount of any other credit applicable in that year, multiplied by:

subparagraph.text: 50% for the first taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
40% for the second taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
30% for the third taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
20% for the fourth taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
10% for the fifth taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.

paragraph.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide additional eligibility requirements.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City may provide for procedures for the submission of an application for a property tax credit under this subsection and the granting of the credit, including procedures for the granting of a partial credit for property qualifying for the credit for less than a full taxable year.
A newly constructed market-rate rental housing project may not qualify for the first taxable year of a tax credit under this subsection after June 30, 2001.
An ordinance of the Mayor and City Council authorizing tax credits in accordance with this subsection shall require:

subparagraph.text: the development of a method, to be approved by the Board of Estimates, for analysis of the public costs and benefits of the tax credits; and
an annual report to the Board of Estimates and to the Mayor and City Council of the results and findings of that analysis.

subsection.text: The governing body of Baltimore County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: real property that is owned by the Harford Park Improvement Association of Baltimore County, Incorporated;
property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Lynch Point Improvement Association, Incorporated, of River Drive in Baltimore County; and
used only for a community or civic purpose;

paragraph.text: real property that is owned by the Chestnut Ridge Improvement Association of Baltimore County, Incorporated; and
property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Relay Improvement Association of Baltimore County, Incorporated; and

used only for a community, civic, educational, recreational, or library purpose, if the use is not contingent on the payment of compensation, unless the compensation is used only to improve or maintain the property.

subsection.text: The governing body of Baltimore County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: real property that is owned by the Twin River Protective and Improvement Association, Incorporated;
real property that is owned by the Bowley’s Quarters Improvement Association, Incorporated;
real property that is owned by the Oliver Beach Improvement Association, Incorporated;
real property that is owned by the Baltimore County Game and Fish Association;
real property that is owned by the Eastfield Civic Association, Incorporated;
real property that is owned by the Rockaway Beach Improvement Association;
real property that is used only for and occupied by the Fire Museum of Maryland;
