“Benefit limited liability company” means a Maryland limited liability company that elects to be a benefit limited liability company and complies with Title 4A, Subtitle 11 of the Corporations and Associations Article.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Montgomery County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this subsection against the county property tax imposed on real or personal property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned or leased by a benefit corporation or benefit limited liability company;
not used for residential purposes; and
used in a trade or business by a benefit corporation or benefit limited liability company.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Montgomery County may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: criteria for eligibility and certification for the tax credit;
the amount of the tax credit;
the duration of the tax credit, for a period not to exceed 10 years;
regulations and procedures for the application, certification, and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit;
limited aggregate amounts of tax credits granted under this subsection; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the tax credit under this subsection.

subsection.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: real property:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Maryland Jaycees, Incorporated; and
used in the operation of a charitable nonprofit educational or rehabilitation institution of the kind that is exempted under § 7–202 of this article; and

paragraph.text: real property owned by the Prince George’s County Chamber of Commerce Foundation, Inc., if the real property:

subparagraph.text: is acquired on or after November 24, 1973; and
is not used for a commercial purpose.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against county property tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: real property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by a nonprofit community civic association or corporation;
dedicated by plat or deed restriction to the use of the lot owners in the community, if the use is not contingent on the payment of:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: dues to the association or corporation, unless dues are used only to improve or maintain the real property of the community; or
compensation for admission to or use of the real property, unless the compensation is used only to improve or maintain the real property of the community;

subparagraph.text: real property that is owned by the Piscataway Hills Citizens Association;
real property that is improved to promote housing, community redevelopment, and business revitalization;
real property used by the property owner to provide child care for the children of at least 25 employees;
real property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by the American Center for Physics, Inc.;
leased by the American Center for Physics, Inc. to affiliated societies; and
used only for nonprofit activities relating to the advancement and diffusion of the knowledge of physics and its application to human welfare;

subparagraph.text: subject to the condition established under paragraph (6) of this subsection, residential real property that is located within an area that the governing body determines is adversely impacted by its proximity to a refuse disposal system for which a permit has been issued under § 9–204 of the Environment Article;
real property that is owned by the Kettering–Largo–Mitchellville Boys and Girls Club; and

agricultural land, including any farm improvement used in connection with an activity that is recognized by the Department as an approved agricultural activity, that is subject to State or county agricultural land preservation programs.

paragraph.text: The amount of a property tax credit granted under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection is a percentage of the actual cost of the improvements as the governing body of Prince George’s County determines after reassessment by the supervisor. The property tax credit may not be more than the increased tax that results from the improvements as the supervisor determines.
A property tax credit granted under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection may not be granted for more than 5 years.
The governing body of Prince George’s County shall define the improvements that are eligible for a tax credit under paragraph (1)(iii) of this subsection.
For purposes of the property tax credit granted under paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: at least 50% of the employees whose children receive child care shall be employed by the property owner;

in order to qualify for the tax credit, the property owner shall provide the child care in an area of the property that is set aside and dedicated by the property owner exclusively for the child care; and
the amount of the tax credit may not exceed $1,000 or the amount of the county property tax attributable to the area of the property used for child care due in a taxable year, whichever is less.
In this paragraph, “environmental surcharges” means tipping fees that:

sub-subparagraph.text: are paid to the county by the user of a refuse disposal system; and
have been set at a specific amount per ton of refuse that is deposited at the site of the disposal system.

subparagraph.text: A property tax credit may not be granted under paragraph (1)(vi) of this subsection unless the governing body of Prince George’s County approves the use of environmental surcharges to offset the total amount of the property tax credits granted.

subsection.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax or special district tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: property that is owned by the Chapel Hill Citizens’ Association;
property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Clinton Boys and Girls Club; and
used only for nonprofit athletic recreation;

paragraph.text: property that is owned by the East Pines Citizens’ Association;
property that is owned by the Lions Club of Bowie;
property that is owned by the Prince George’s Jaycees, Incorporated;
property that is owned by the Suitland Civic Association, Incorporated;
real property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Prince George’s County Parks and Recreation Foundation; and
not used for a commercial purpose;

paragraph.text: property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Freestate Riding Club, Inc.; and
used only for nonprofit athletic recreation;

paragraph.text: property that is owned by a boys and girls club in Prince George’s County that is chartered by the Prince George’s County Boys and Girls Club, Incorporated;
property that is owned by the Lake Arbor Foundation, Incorporated;
property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the George A. and Carmel D. Aman Memorial Trust; and
known as the George Washington House;

paragraph.text: property that:

subparagraph.text: is owned by Crescent Cities Charities, Incorporated; and
is not exempt from taxation under Title 7 of this article; and

paragraph.text: property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by a nonprofit, tax–exempt community development corporation qualified under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code;
not used for a commercial purpose; and
located in Prince George’s County on Maryland Route 202 at the intersection with St. Joseph’s Drive.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on owner–occupied, residential real property that is purchased from July 1, 2000 through June 30, 2002, specific to two geographic areas of Prince George’s County that:

subparagraph.text: contain up to 2,500 single–family dwellings in the aggregate; and
are designated by the County Executive of Prince George’s County for participation in a demonstration project for neighborhood preservation and stabilization.

paragraph.text: In order to qualify for the credit under this subsection:

subparagraph.text: for the 12–month period immediately prior to purchasing the property, the individual’s principal residence may not have been located in the geographic areas designated under this subsection, unless the individual was not an owner of the property that was the individual’s principal residence;
the designated geographic areas shall be located within two of the following areas:

sub-subparagraph.text: a priority funding area, as defined in § 5–7B–02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
a revitalization tax credit district, as defined in § 10–235.02 established under the Prince George’s County Code; or
an enterprise zone, as defined in § 5–701 of the Economic Development Article; and

subparagraph.text: the residential real property must have been purchased in conformance with a resolution adopted by the County Executive that is approved by the County Council.

paragraph.text: The property tax credit shall equal:

subparagraph.text: 40% of the county property tax for each of the first 5 taxable years after the purchase of the real property;
35% of the county property tax for the 6th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
30% of the county property tax for the 7th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
25% of the county property tax for the 8th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
20% of the county property tax for the 9th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
15% of the county property tax for the 10th taxable year after the purchase of the real property; and
0% of the county property tax for each taxable year thereafter.

paragraph.text: The property tax credit shall first apply to the taxable year beginning after the date of the purchase of the eligible real property.
The governing body of Prince George’s County may provide, by law, for any other provision necessary to carry out the property tax credit under this subsection.

subparagraph.text: The County Executive of Prince George’s County shall hold a public hearing prior to the final designation of the geographic areas under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
Designation of geographic areas shall be made by a resolution adopted by the County Executive and approved by the County Council.

paragraph.text: The Prince George’s County Department of Finance shall provide, on an annual basis to those individuals qualifying for the property tax credit under this subsection, a statement certifying qualification for the property tax credit and the amount of the property tax credit being granted. The statement may be provided on or with the annual property tax bill or in another manner as chosen by the local government.

In order to be eligible for a property tax credit under this subsection, an individual shall apply for the credit at least 6 months after the title to the residential property has been transferred to the individual.
The property tax credit granted under this subsection terminates on the sale of the property.

A property owner who has been granted a property tax credit for agricultural land under subsection (b)(1)(viii) of this section and subsequently withdraws the property from a State or county agricultural land preservation program shall be liable for:

subparagraph.text: all property taxes for which the property owner would have been liable if a property tax credit for agricultural land had not been granted under subsection (b)(1)(viii) of this section for a period not exceeding 10 years from the date that the property was subject to a State or county agricultural land preservation program;
interest on the total tax liability as required under § 14–605 of this article; and
a penalty as required under § 14–703 of this article.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may provide, by law, any procedural or enforcement provision necessary to carry out this subsection.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Green business” means a business that is certified by Prince George’s County and:

sub-subparagraph.text: primarily distributes, manufactures, markets, or sells green products;
primarily provides services relating to green products; or
primarily provides research and development relating to green products.

subparagraph.text: “Green product” means a product that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is energy or water efficient;
uses healthy, nontoxic materials;
is made from recycled or renewable resources; or
makes current products more energy efficient.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on real or personal property that is owned or leased by a certified green business.
The governing body of Prince George’s County may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: criteria for eligibility and certification for the tax credit under this subsection;
the amount and duration of the tax credit under this subsection;
regulations and procedures for the application, certification, and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the tax credit.

The County Council and County Executive of Prince George’s County shall jointly appoint an advisory board to provide advice to the governing body of Prince George’s County regarding the implementation of paragraph (3) of this subsection.
A majority of the members of the advisory board shall be affiliated with a nonprofit environmental organization in the State.

paragraph.text: The governing body of a municipal corporation in Prince George’s County may, by resolution, establish revitalization districts for the purpose of encouraging redevelopment.

The governing body of a municipal corporation in Prince George’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property located within a revitalization district established under this subsection that is:

subparagraph.text: constructed or substantially redeveloped in conformance with adopted eligibility criteria; and
reassessed as a result of the construction or redevelopment at a higher value than that assessed prior to the construction or redevelopment.

paragraph.text: The governing body of a municipal corporation in Prince George’s County may provide by law:

subparagraph.text: criteria for the designation of a revitalization district;
criteria for eligibility for the property tax credit under this subsection;
the amount and duration of the tax credit;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the tax credit under this subsection.

subsection.text: The governing body of Queen Anne’s County and the governing body of a municipal corporation in Queen Anne’s County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county and municipal corporation property tax imposed on property that is not used for a commercial purpose and is owned by:

paragraph.text: the Ingleside Community Group;
the Lions Club of Kent Island, Maryland, Inc.;
the Price Community Club, Incorporated;
the Ruthsburg Community Club, Incorporated;
the Sudlersville Community Betterment Club, Incorporated;
the Templeville Community Association, Incorporated;
the William T. Roe Memorial Range; or
the Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department, Incorporated.

subsection.text: The governing body of Queen Anne’s County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on real property that is:

paragraph.text: owned by the Maryland Jaycees, Incorporated; and
used as the principal office of the organization.

subsection.text: The governing body of Queen Anne’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on real property that is:

paragraph.text: owned by the Wildfowl Trust of North America, Inc.; and
is used solely for:

subparagraph.text: the maintenance of a natural area for public use;
a sanctuary for wildlife;
the environmental education of the public;
scientific research in ornithology; or
the general management of wildlife.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Queen Anne’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on real property owned by a business that:

subparagraph.text: makes significant real property improvements in the county, including construction, reconstruction, rehabilitation, or expansion of a nonresidential structure; and
employs at least 25 new additional full–time employees.

paragraph.text: In each year following the year in which the nonresidential real property improvements are completed and assessed, a tax credit granted under this subsection may not exceed:

subparagraph.text: 80% of the amount of the county property tax imposed on the increased assessment in the first taxable year;
60% of the amount of the county property tax imposed on the increased assessment in the second taxable year;
40% of the amount of the county property tax imposed on the increased assessment in the third taxable year;
20% of the amount of the county property tax imposed on the increased assessment in the fourth taxable year; and
0% of the amount of the county property tax imposed on the increased assessment in the fifth taxable year and all taxable years after the fifth taxable year.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Queen Anne’s County may further define, fix, or limit the amount, terms, scope, and duration of any credit authorized under this subsection.

The governing body of Queen Anne’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this subsection against the county property tax imposed on real property that is owned by a foster parent of a child.
The governing body of Queen Anne’s County may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this subsection;
the amount and duration of the tax credit under this subsection;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this subsection.

paragraph.text: The governing body of St. Mary’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against county property tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by the St. George’s Island Improvement Association, Incorporated; and
used only for community or civic purposes;

subparagraph.text: real property that is owned by the Seventh District Optimist Youth Foundation, Inc.;
real property, including any improvements, that is subject to a State or a county land preservation program; and
real property that:

sub-subparagraph.text: was formerly used solely as a tobacco barn; and
is subject to a tobacco buyout agreement.

paragraph.text: In authorizing a credit under paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection, the governing body of the county may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the credit;
the duration of the credit; and
any other provision necessary to administer the credit.

paragraph.text: The governing body of St. Mary’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on personal property.
A law adopted under paragraph (1) of this subsection may provide for:

subparagraph.text: the amount of a credit;
the subclasses of personal property under § 8–101(c) of this article to which the credit applies; and
other provisions necessary to administer the credit.

paragraph.text: The governing body of St. Mary’s County or of a municipal corporation in St. Mary’s County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is:

subparagraph.text: leased to a nonprofit school; and
used exclusively for primary or secondary educational purposes.

paragraph.text: A property tax credit granted under this subsection shall continue as long as the property is in compliance with the terms of this subsection.

section.text: The governing body of Somerset County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against county property tax imposed on real property owned by the Crisfield Heritage Foundation, Inc.

subsection.text: The governing body of Talbot County and the governing body of a municipal corporation in Talbot County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county and municipal corporation property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: property that:

subparagraph.text: is owned by the Academy of the Arts, Easton, Maryland, Incorporated;
is used primarily for the purpose of the organization; and
is not used primarily for revenue or income–producing purposes;

paragraph.text: property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by the Bailey’s Neck Park Association; and
used for charitable purposes;

paragraph.text: property that is owned by the Maryland Ornithological Society, Incorporated, or any of its chapters; and
property that is owned by the Tuckahoe Steam and Gas Association, Incorporated.

subsection.text: The governing body of Talbot County or of a municipal corporation in Talbot County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: property that is owned by the Chesapeake Audubon Society, Inc. and is used solely for:

subparagraph.text: the environmental education of the public; and
the maintenance of:

sub-subparagraph.text: a natural area for public use; or
a sanctuary for wildlife; and

paragraph.text: personal property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by Chesapeake Wildlife Heritage, Incorporated;
used primarily for the purpose of the organization; and
not used primarily for revenue or income–producing purposes.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Talbot County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on real property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned or occupied by a commercial or industrial business that is currently or will be doing business in Talbot County; and
new construction or a substantial improvement to the real property.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Talbot County may:

subparagraph.text: set, by law, the amount, terms, scope, and duration of a credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection;
adopt any provision necessary to administer a credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
provide for any other restriction or condition considered desirable on the granting of a credit under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Talbot County or of a municipal corporation in Talbot County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on personal property.
The governing body of Talbot County or of a municipal corporation in Talbot County may, by law:

subparagraph.text: set the amount, terms, scope, and duration of a credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection;
designate subclasses of personal property under § 8–101(c) of this article to which a credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection applies;
provide for any restriction or condition considered desirable on the granting of a credit under paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
adopt any other provisions necessary to administer a credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Talbot County or of a municipal corporation in Talbot County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax that is imposed on real property that is:

subparagraph.text: owned by Habitat for Humanity of Talbot & Dorchester Counties, Inc. with the intention of relinquishing ownership in the immediate future;
used exclusively for the purpose of rehabilitation and transfer to a private owner; and
not occupied by administrative or warehouse buildings owned by Habitat for Humanity.

paragraph.text: Habitat for Humanity of Talbot & Dorchester Counties, Inc. shall submit an annual written report to the governing body of Talbot County documenting:

subparagraph.text: all of Habitat for Humanity of Talbot & Dorchester Counties, Inc.’s real property holdings in Talbot County; and
all transactions involving Habitat for Humanity of Talbot & Dorchester Counties, Inc.’s real property holdings in Talbot County.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Talbot County or of a municipal corporation in Talbot County may, by law:

subparagraph.text: set the amount, terms, scope, and duration of a credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection; and
adopt any provision necessary to administer a credit granted under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Washington County or of a municipal corporation in Washington County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: new construction or on an improvement to existing property;
property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by a nonprofit civic association;
used only for a community, civic, educational, or library purpose; and

unless the compensation is used only to improve or maintain the property, use of the property is not contingent on the payment of compensation for admission to or use of the property and failure to pay compensation is not a reason to deny admission to or use of the property;

subparagraph.text: real property that is owned by the Women’s Club of Hagerstown, Inc.;
property that is owned by the Rohrersville Cornet Band of Washington County;
real property that is owned and occupied as the principal residence of an individual serving as:

sub-subparagraph.text: a volunteer firefighter;
a member of the fire police; or
an emergency medical technician; or

subparagraph.text: real property that is owned by the Hagerstown Soccer Club, Inc.

paragraph.text: The law adopted under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection shall specify:

subparagraph.text: the qualifications for the tax credit;
the amount of the property tax credit, based on a percentage of the cost of any new construction or of any improvement to existing property, and not based on the increase in the assessment; and
the duration of the tax credit.

paragraph.text: In authorizing a credit under paragraph (1)(v) of this subsection, the governing body of the county or municipal corporation may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the credit;
the duration of the credit; and
any other provision necessary to administer the credit.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Washington County shall grant a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: property that is owned by the District 15 Civic Association, Incorporated, of Big Pool, Maryland; and
real property on which an improvement is made to an existing structure that is located in a historic district.

paragraph.text: A property tax credit granted under paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection shall be:

subparagraph.text: the following percentage of the increase that is due to the improvement:

sub-subparagraph.text: 100% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 1st and 2nd taxable years that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax;
80% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 3rd taxable year that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax;
60% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 4th taxable year that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax;
40% of the increase in the assessment of the real property in the 5th taxable year that the improved structure is subject to the county property tax; and

subparagraph.text: ended after the 5th taxable year that the improved structure is subject to county property tax.

subsection.text: The governing body of Washington County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on:

paragraph.text: personal property that is owned by Mid–East Milk Lab Services, Incorporated; and
real property that is subject to the county’s agricultural land preservation program.

In this subsection, “qualifying business” means an industrial or commercial business that is or will be doing business in Washington County, employing five or more full–time employees on a regular basis, and that is initially building or making substantial improvements or otherwise undertaking new construction work.

Notwithstanding § 9–301(b) of this subtitle and subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, the governing body of Washington County may grant to a qualifying business a property tax credit against all or part of the county property tax levied on real or personal property of the qualifying business for a period not exceeding 5 years.
A property tax credit granted under this subsection may phase in the payment of county property taxes over the period of the credit.
The governing body of Washington County may grant a property tax credit under this subsection only at a public meeting. The decision of the governing body shall be included in its minutes.

The governing body of Washington County may grant a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on renovated or rehabilitated business real property located in a priority funding area as designated in Title 5, Subtitle 7B of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the governing body of the county may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount of the credit;
the duration of the credit; and
any other provision necessary to administer the credit.

paragraph.text: A tax credit under this subsection may not exceed the amount of additional property tax assessed as a result of the renovation or rehabilitation.
A tax credit under this subsection is available to a qualified property for no more than 5 years.

subparagraph.text: In this subsection the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Affiliate” means a person:

sub-subparagraph.text: that directly or indirectly owns at least 80% of a business entity; or
at least 80% of which is owned, directly or indirectly, by a business entity.

subparagraph.text: “Business entity” means a person conducting a trade or business in the State that is subject to the State individual or corporate income tax or insurance premiums tax.
“Full–time position” means a position requiring at least 840 hours of an individual’s time during at least 24 weeks in a 6–month period.

“New or expanded premises” means commercial or industrial real property, including a building or part of a building that has not been previously occupied, where a business entity or its affiliates locate to conduct business.

sub-subparagraph.text: “New permanent full–time position” means a position that is:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a full–time position of indefinite duration;
located in Washington County;
newly created, as a result of the establishment or expansion of a business facility in the county; and
filled.

sub-subparagraph.text: “New permanent full–time position” does not include a position that is:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: created when an employment function is shifted from an existing business facility of the business entity or its affiliates located in Washington County to another business facility of the same entity or its affiliates, if the position does not represent a net new job in the county;
created through a change in ownership of a trade or business;
created through a consolidation, merger, or restructuring of a business entity or its affiliates, if the position does not represent a net new job in the county;

created when an employment function is contractually shifted from an existing business entity or its affiliates located in the county to another business entity or its affiliates, if the position does not represent a net new job in the county; or
filled for a period of less than 12 months.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Washington County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on real property owned or leased by a business entity that meets the requirements specified for the tax credit under this subsection.

To qualify for a property tax credit under this subsection, before a business entity obtains the new or expanded premises or hires employees to fill the new permanent full–time positions at the new or expanded premises, the business entity shall provide written notification to the governing body of Washington County stating:

subparagraph.text: that the business entity intends to claim the property tax credit; and
when the business entity expects to obtain the new or expanded premises and hire the required number of employees in the new permanent full–time positions.
To qualify for a property tax credit under this subsection, an existing business entity in the county shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: obtain at least an additional 1,500 square feet of new or expanded premises by purchasing newly constructed premises, constructing new premises, causing new premises to be constructed, or leasing previously unoccupied premises; and
employ at least one individual in a new permanent full–time position during a 12–month period, during which period the business entity also must obtain and occupy the new or expanded premises.

subparagraph.text: To qualify for the property tax credit under this subsection, a new business entity locating in the county shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: obtain at least 2,500 square feet of new or expanded premises by purchasing newly constructed premises, constructing new premises, causing new premises to be constructed, or leasing previously unoccupied premises; and
employ at least five individuals in new permanent full–time positions during a 24–month period, during which period the business entity also must obtain and occupy the new or expanded premises.

subparagraph.text: If an existing business entity in the county meets the requirements of paragraph (4)(i) of this subsection, the property tax credit granted under this subsection shall equal a percentage of the amount of property tax imposed on the assessment of the new or expanded premises, as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: 52% in the first and second taxable years;
39% in the third and fourth taxable years; and
26% in the fifth and sixth taxable years.

subparagraph.text: If a new business entity locating in the county meets the requirements of paragraph (4)(ii) of this subsection, the property tax credit granted under this subsection shall equal a percentage of the amount of property tax imposed on the assessment of the new or expanded premises, as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: 30% in the first and second taxable years;
20% in the third and fourth taxable years; and
10% in the fifth and sixth taxable years.

paragraph.text: The lessor of real property granted a property tax credit under this subsection shall reduce the amount of taxes for which a business entity is contractually liable under the lease agreement by the amount of any credit granted under this subsection for improvements made by the business entity.
The governing body of Washington County shall provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the specific requirements for eligibility for a property tax credit authorized under this subsection;
any additional limitations on eligibility for the credit; and
any other provision appropriate to implement the credit.

subsection.text: The governing body of Wicomico County and the governing body of a municipal corporation in Wicomico County may grant a property tax credit under this section against the county and municipal corporation property tax imposed on property that is owned by the East Side Men’s Club, Inc.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Wicomico County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on agricultural land and agricultural easements, not including any improvements, that are located in an agricultural preservation district.
In establishing a tax credit under this subsection, the governing body of Wicomico County shall specify:

subparagraph.text: the amount and duration of the credit;
the qualification and application procedures for the credit;
the circumstances under which the credit shall terminate;
the liability of the property owner in the event of termination of the credit; and
any other requirement or procedure related to the credit and considered necessary.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Wicomico County or the governing body of a municipal corporation in Wicomico County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on property that is owned by the Salisbury Area Chamber of Commerce, Inc.
The governing body of Wicomico County or of a municipal corporation in Wicomico County may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount and duration of a property tax credit under this subsection; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this subsection.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Worcester County may grant, by law, a property tax credit under this section against the county property tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by the Berlin Community Improvement Association, Incorporated, of Worcester County; and
used only for the nonprofit activities of the organization;

subparagraph.text: property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by the Marlin Park Association, Incorporated; and
used for nonprofit purposes;

subparagraph.text: property that is owned or leased by the Greater Ocean City Health Service Corporation; and
property that is owned by the Ocean City, Maryland Chamber of Commerce.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Worcester County may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount and duration of a property tax credit under this section; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this section.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Worcester County or the governing body of a municipal corporation in Worcester County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on:

subparagraph.text: property that is owned by the Pocomoke City Chamber of Commerce;
real property that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: owned by the Mayor and City Council of Ocean City;
leased to the Sinepuxent Pier and Improvement Company, Incorporated; and
known as the Ocean City Amusement and Fishing Pier; and

subparagraph.text: real property that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is located in Ocean City on or west of Route 528;
consists of at least 30 acres; and
is actually used exclusively for the operation of an amusement park.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Worcester County or of a municipal corporation in Worcester County may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount and duration of a property tax credit under this subsection;
additional eligibility criteria for a property tax credit under this subsection;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out this subsection.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “historically operated amusement park” means real property that is used for mechanical amusement rides, games, and concessions that:

subparagraph.text: have been continuously owned by members of the same family or by entities of which members of the same family own a controlling interest;
have been operated at the same general location for a period of more than 100 years and continue to be operated at the same general location; and
have created a tourist destination at a boardwalk.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Worcester County or of a municipal corporation in Worcester County may grant, by law, a property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on real property that is actually used as a historically operated amusement park.
The governing body of Worcester County or of a municipal corporation in Worcester County may provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: the amount and duration of the property tax credit under this subsection;
additional eligibility criteria for the tax credit under this subsection;
regulations and procedures for the application and uniform processing of requests for the tax credit; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the credit under this subsection.

subsection.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City and the governing body of Baltimore County shall grant a property tax credit against the county property tax imposed on owner-occupied, residential real property that:

subparagraph.text: is purchased from July 1, 1996 through June 30, 2002 in a geographic area of Baltimore City, that contains between 800 and 1,500 single-family dwellings; or
is purchased from July 1, 1996 through June 30, 2005 in either of two geographic areas of Baltimore County, that contain between:

sub-subparagraph.text: 800 and 1,400 single-family dwellings in one geographic area; and
2,000 and 2,400 single-family dwellings in another geographic area; and

paragraph.text: is designated by the Mayor of Baltimore City or the County Executive of Baltimore County, respectively, for participation in a demonstration project for neighborhood preservation and stabilization.

subsection.text: In order to qualify for the credit under this section:

paragraph.text: for the 12-month period immediately prior to purchasing the property, the individual’s principal residence may not have been located in the geographic areas designated under this section, unless the individual was not an owner of the property that was the individual’s principal residence; and

the residential real property must have been purchased in conformance with the guidelines regarding government housing assistance programs established by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City and the governing body of Baltimore County.

subsection.text: The property tax credit shall equal:

paragraph.text: 40% of the county property tax for each of the first 5 taxable years after the purchase of the real property;
35% of the county property tax for the 6th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
30% of the county property tax for the 7th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
25% of the county property tax for the 8th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
20% of the county property tax for the 9th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
15% of the county property tax for the 10th taxable year after the purchase of the real property; and
0% of the county property tax for each taxable year thereafter.

subsection.text: The property tax credit shall first apply to the taxable year beginning after the date of the purchase of the eligible real property.
The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City and the governing body of Baltimore County may provide, by law, for any other provision necessary to carry out the property tax credit under this section.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City and the governing body of Baltimore County shall hold a public hearing prior to the final designation of the geographic area under subsection (a) of this section.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City and the governing body of Baltimore County shall provide, on an annual basis to those individuals qualifying for the property tax credit under this section, a statement certifying qualification for the property tax credit and the amount of the property tax credit being granted. The statement may be provided on or with the annual property tax bill or in another manner as chosen by the local government.

In order to be eligible for a property tax credit under this section, an individual shall apply for the credit within 6 months after the title to the residential property has been transferred to the individual.
In this section, “dwelling”:

paragraph.text: means a newly constructed or substantially rehabilitated dwelling in Baltimore City, that is unsold, unrented, and unoccupied; and
does not include land.

subsection.text: A property tax credit granted under this section applies only to the county property tax.
The governing body of Baltimore City may grant a property tax credit not exceeding 100% against the county tax imposed on the dwelling.

paragraph.text: A property tax credit under this section may not be granted:

subparagraph.text: for any dwelling that is used as an office or sample home by the builder or the owner; or
for more than 3 dwellings of an owner each year.

paragraph.text: This section does not change the regular assessment procedures that are applicable in Baltimore City.

subsection.text: The governing body of Baltimore City may provide for procedures necessary to apply for a property tax credit under this section.

When the owner of a dwelling applies to the governing body of Baltimore City for a property tax credit under this section, the owner shall certify that the dwelling is unsold, unrented, and unoccupied.
A recipient of a property tax credit under this section shall send immediately to the governing body of Baltimore City a notice that the dwelling has been sold, rented, or occupied.
A property tax credit granted under this section is available:

paragraph.text: as long as the dwelling remains unsold, unrented, and unoccupied; and
over a continuous period of time not exceeding 1 year for any dwelling.

subsection.text: If a recipient of a property tax credit under this section fails to comply with the provisions of this section, the property tax credit under this section is forfeited immediately.
In this section, “county” means:

paragraph.text: Anne Arundel County;
Howard County;
Montgomery County; and
Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: Instead of a property tax credit, the governing body of a county may provide, by law, a grant to any eligible elderly or disabled renter.
The governing body of a county may establish any qualification for the grant, including an income limit.
The governing body of a county shall fund the grant from the appropriate county source.
This section may not be construed to deny the governing body of a county the power to alter, amend, or repeal any law adopted under this section.
In this title, “property tax” includes a taxing district tax.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this title, property newly annexed into a municipal corporation during a period shall be treated as initially added to the tax roll for that period.
The imposition of the municipal property tax for a partial year on property newly annexed into a municipal corporation shall have no effect on the tax setoff under § 6-305 or § 6-306 of this article.

Expenses incurred by a county for billing and collecting municipal corporation property taxes for a partial year on property newly annexed into the municipal corporation shall be chargeable to the municipal corporation for which the property taxes are collected.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, property tax is due on July 1 in each taxable year.

Except as provided in § 10-204.3 of this title, property tax that is due on July 1 of the tax year may be paid without interest on or before September 30 of the tax year, and is in arrears after September 30 of the tax year.
Property tax for a full year that is imposed as of a semiannual date of finality may be paid without interest:

paragraph.text: on or before September 30, if the bill is submitted on or before August 31 of a tax year; or
on or before 30 days after the date the tax bill is received or reasonably should have been received or available if the tax bill is submitted after September 1 of the tax year.

subsection.text: Personal property tax may be paid without interest or penalty:

paragraph.text: on or before September 30, if the bill is submitted on or before August 31 of a tax year; or
on or before 30 days after the date the tax bill is received or reasonably should have been received or available if the tax bill is submitted after September 1 of the tax year.

subsection.text: Except as provided by § 10-104 of this subtitle, real property that during the period from July 1 to December 31, both inclusive, is completed or is otherwise initially added to the tax roll shall be taxed for the 6-month period from January 1 to the following June 30, both inclusive, at 50% of the annual State, county, municipal corporation, or taxing district property tax rate that is in effect for that taxable year.
The property tax imposed under this section is due on the later of:

paragraph.text: January 1 of the taxable year; or
the date after January 1 of the taxable year that the tax bill is received or reasonably should have been received or available.

subsection.text: Property tax imposed under this section may be paid without interest or penalty on or before 30 days after the date the tax bill is mailed or made available.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may impose, by law, a county or municipal corporation property tax on real property that during the period from July 1 to September 30, both inclusive, is completed or is otherwise initially added to the tax roll. If imposed, the tax shall be for the 9-month period from October 1 to the following June 30, both inclusive, at 75% of the annual county or municipal corporation tax rate that is in effect for that taxable year.
The county or municipal corporation property tax imposed under this section is due on the later of:

paragraph.text: October 1 of the taxable year; or
the date that the tax bill is received or reasonably should have been received or is available.

subsection.text: The county or municipal corporation property tax imposed under this section may be paid without interest or penalty on or before 30 days after the date the tax bill is mailed or made available.

The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or of a municipal corporation may impose, by law, a county or municipal corporation property tax on real property that, during the period from January 1 to March 30, both inclusive, is completed or otherwise is initially added to the tax roll. If imposed, the tax shall be for the 3-month period from April 1 to June 30, both inclusive, at 25% of the annual county or municipal corporation tax rate that is in effect for that taxable year.
The county or municipal corporation property tax imposed under this section is due on the later of:

paragraph.text: April 1 of the taxable year; or
the date that the tax bill is received or reasonably should have been received or is available.

subsection.text: County or municipal corporation property tax imposed under this section may be paid without interest or penalty on or before 30 days after the date the tax bill is mailed or made available.

Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of Montgomery County, of Anne Arundel County, of Howard County, of Baltimore County, or of Prince George’s County may authorize, by law, a payment deferral of county property tax for residential real property occupied as the principal residence of the owner.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may provide for the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section to apply to real property rezoned at the initiative of Prince George’s County after July 1, 1974.
The governing body of Howard County may provide for the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section to apply to real property rezoned at the initiative of Howard County after July 1, 1984.

The governing body of Baltimore County may provide for the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section to apply to real property rezoned at the initiative of Baltimore County after January 1, 1960.

subsection.text: In Prince George’s County, Baltimore County, and Howard County, the real property eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section is limited to the dwelling and curtilage, not exceeding 5 acres, as determined by the supervisor.

The Montgomery County, Anne Arundel County, Howard County, Baltimore County, or Prince George’s County property tax deferral shall be calculated on any increase in assessment that results directly from a change in zoning classification to a higher intensity use and that was initiated by a government.

The governing body of Montgomery County, of Anne Arundel County, of Howard County, of Baltimore County, or of Prince George’s County may limit the time period during which the payment of county property tax may be deferred.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “staged–development zoning classification” includes M–A–C, L–A–C, E–I–A, I–3, and other similar comprehensive design or staged–development zoning classifications.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection and notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of Prince George’s County may authorize by law a payment deferral of the county property tax for the owner of undeveloped land that is rezoned for industrial or commercial use under a staged–development zoning classification if:

subparagraph.text: the industrial or commercial land in the proposed development is at least 25 acres;

as determined by the supervisor, the county property tax deferred for each taxable year does not exceed the county property tax on any increase in assessment that would otherwise result directly from the change in zoning classification to industrial or commercial use; and
the deferred payment of county property tax is not for land in the proposed development that is zoned for other than industrial or commercial use.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may not authorize a payment deferral for county property tax for real property located in a development district established under Title 12, Subtitle 2 of the Economic Development Article.
A payment deferral under this section begins on the effective date of the later of:

subparagraph.text: the Prince George’s County law authorizing the payment deferral; or
the change in zoning.

paragraph.text: The payment deferral under this section does not apply to any taxable year before the effective date under paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection.
The payment deferral under this section may not be authorized for more than 5 years and ends when:

subparagraph.text: a building permit is issued to construct a building on the land subject to this section; or

except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the land subject to this section is rezoned at the request of the owner to a zoning classification that makes the land ineligible for county property tax deferral under this section.

paragraph.text: If a permit is issued to construct a building on any land that is subject to this section and the remainder of the land meets the acreage requirements of subsection (a)(2)(i) of this section, the county property tax may be deferred on the remainder of the land.

subsection.text: The county property tax that is deferred under this section, and any interest specified in the law authorizing the deferral, are due on the earlier of:

paragraph.text: 5 years from the deferral; or
when the deferral ends under subsection (c)(1) of this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “revitalization district” means a district designated by resolution adopted by the Prince George’s County Council and approved by the County Executive or designated by the governing body of a municipal corporation in Prince George’s County.

paragraph.text: It is found and declared that there exists within Prince George’s County:

subparagraph.text: a number of economically depressed areas in need of revitalization; and
deteriorating communities.

paragraph.text: Older commercial centers are decaying. A need exists to provide an incentive to property owners to revive the older communities. New business in these areas would bring about new housing and new jobs. The establishment of revitalization districts with the provision of a tax deferral will give property owners an incentive to renovate deteriorating properties.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the governing body of Prince George’s County or any municipal corporation within Prince George’s County may by resolution establish revitalization districts for the purpose of encouraging revitalization.

The governing body of Prince George’s County may not establish a revitalization district within the boundaries of a municipal corporation without the approval of the governing body of the municipal corporation.

subsection.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County or the governing body of a municipal corporation in Prince George’s County may authorize, by law, the deferral of increased property taxes imposed by that governing body on real property located within a revitalization district that:

paragraph.text: is substantially renovated after the creation of the revitalization district;
is reassessed as the result of the renovation and is assessed at a higher value than would otherwise have been assessed; and
is eligible for the tax deferral as provided by local law.

subsection.text: The governing body authorizing the tax deferral may authorize, by law, procedures for the determination of eligibility of property for the tax deferral by:

paragraph.text: establishing criteria for the extent of renovation;
requiring approval of the renovation plan; and
requiring the owner of the property to make application for the deferral.

subsection.text: The deferral authorized under this section:

paragraph.text: may apply only to the tax liability increase directly attributable to the value added by the renovation of the property;
may not be granted for a period exceeding 5 years; and
shall constitute a lien on the property until paid in full.
Upon expiration of the deferral, the governing body may provide for payment of the deferred taxes in 1 payment or in annual payments of not more than 5 payments.
Upon transfer of ownership of the property, the governing body may provide for immediate payment of the deferred taxes in 1 payment.

Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of Montgomery County may authorize, by law, a payment deferral of county property tax for residential real property that is occupied as a moderate income, multifamily rental housing facility.

For purposes of the tax payment deferral authorized by this subsection, the governing body of Montgomery County shall define the term “moderate income” through regulations based on § 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937, as amended.

subsection.text: The law adopted under subsection (a)(1) of this section shall specify the terms, conditions, and procedures for the property tax payment deferral, including:

paragraph.text: the amount of the payment deferral;
the duration of the payment deferral; and
the qualifications for the payment deferral.

subsection.text: The property tax payment deferral authorized by subsection (a)(1) of this section shall continue until the property no longer meets the criteria, established by the governing body of Montgomery County, of a moderate income, multifamily rental housing facility.
The accrued deferred property tax is due on property that no longer meets the specified criteria of a moderate income, multifamily rental housing facility.
The unpaid taxes deferred under the authorization of subsection (a)(1) of this section are a lien against the property.

Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of a county may authorize, by law, a payment deferral of county property tax for residential real property occupied as the principal residence of the owner.
An owner is eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section if the owner or at least 1 of the owners:

paragraph.text: has resided in the dwelling for a period of at least 5 consecutive years;

subparagraph.text: is at least 65 years of age;
has been found permanently and totally disabled and has qualified for benefits under:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Social Security Act;
the Railroad Retirement Act;
any federal act for members of the United States armed forces; or
any federal retirement system; or

subparagraph.text: has been found permanently and totally disabled by a county health officer or the Baltimore City Commissioner of Health; and

paragraph.text: meets the income eligibility requirements determined under subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: The governing body of a county that authorizes a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section shall specify:

paragraph.text: the amount of the tax that may be deferred, not exceeding the increase in the county property tax from the date the taxpayer elects to defer the payment of the tax;

restrictions on the amount of the real property eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section, except that the amount of eligible property may not be less than the dwelling and curtilage, as determined by the supervisor;
the duration of the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section;
the rate of interest to be paid on the county property tax payment from the due date without a deferral until the date that the county property tax is paid;
that any mortgagee or beneficiary under a deed of trust be entitled to receive notice of the deferral and of the amount of tax to be deferred; and
the level of income to determine eligibility for the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: The county property tax that is deferred under this section and any interest specified in the law authorizing the deferral are due when the deferral ends as specified in the law authorizing the deferral.

The governing body of a county that authorizes a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section shall specify the cumulative amount of the deferral and related interest in the taxpayer’s annual property tax bill.
A lien shall attach to the property in the amount of all deferred taxes and interest. The lien shall remain attached until the deferred taxes and interest are paid.

The governing body of a county that authorizes a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section shall authorize the deferral by written agreement. The agreement shall reflect the terms and conditions of the deferral including notice of the lien. The agreement shall be recorded in the land records of the county.
Penalties may not be charged during the period of the deferral on any tax payments deferred under this section.

Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of Montgomery County may authorize, by law, a payment deferral of the county property tax for residential real property occupied as the principal residence of the owner.
An owner is eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section if the owner or at least 1 of the owners:

paragraph.text: has resided in the dwelling for a period of at least 5 consecutive years; and
meets the income eligibility requirements determined under subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: The governing body of Montgomery County shall specify:

paragraph.text: the amount of the tax that may be deferred, not exceeding the increase in the county property tax from the date the taxpayer elects to defer the payment of the tax;

restrictions on the amount of the real property eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section, except that the amount of eligible property may not be less than the dwelling and curtilage, as determined by the supervisor;
the duration of the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section;
the rate of interest to be paid on the county property tax payment from the due date without a deferral until the date that the county property tax is paid;
that any mortgagee or beneficiary under a deed of trust be entitled to receive notice of the deferral and of the amount of tax to be deferred; and
the level of income to determine eligibility for the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: The county property tax that is deferred under this section and any interest specified in subsection (c)(4) of this section are due when the deferral ends as specified in subsection (c)(3) of this section or immediately upon transfer of ownership of the property for which the property tax has been deferred.
The governing body of Montgomery County shall specify the cumulative amount of the deferral and related interest in the taxpayer’s annual property tax bill.
A lien shall attach to the property in the amount of all deferred taxes and interest. The lien shall remain attached until the deferred taxes and interest are paid.

The governing body of Montgomery County shall authorize the deferral by written agreement. The agreement shall reflect the terms and conditions of the deferral, including notice of the lien. The agreement shall be recorded in the land records of the county.
Penalties may not be charged during the period of the deferral on any tax payments deferred under this section.

Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of a municipal corporation may authorize, by law, a payment deferral of municipal corporation property tax for residential real property occupied as the principal residence of the owner.
An owner is eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section if the owner or at least 1 of the owners:

paragraph.text: has resided in the dwelling for a period of at least 5 consecutive years;

subparagraph.text: is at least 65 years of age;

subsection.text: The governing body of a municipal corporation that authorizes a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section shall specify:

restrictions on the amount of the real property eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section, except that the amount of eligible property may not be less than the dwelling and curtilage, as determined by the supervisor;
the duration of the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section;
the rate of interest to be paid on the municipal corporation property tax payment from the due date without a deferral until the date that the municipal corporation property tax is paid;
that any mortgagee or beneficiary under a deed of trust be entitled to receive notice of the deferral and of the amount of tax to be deferred; and
the level of income to determine eligibility for the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section.

subsection.text: The municipal corporation property tax that is deferred under this section and any interest specified in the law authorizing the deferral are due when the deferral ends as specified in the law authorizing the deferral.

The governing body of a municipal corporation that authorizes a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section shall specify the cumulative amount of the deferral and related interest in the taxpayer’s annual property tax bill.
A lien shall attach to the property in the amount of all deferred taxes and interest. The lien shall remain attached until the deferred taxes and interest are paid.

The governing body of a municipal corporation that authorizes a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section shall authorize the deferral by written agreement. The agreement shall reflect the terms and conditions of the deferral including notice of the lien. The agreement shall be recorded in the land records of the county.
Penalties may not be charged during the period of the deferral on any tax payments deferred under this section.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Owner–occupied residential property” means the principal residence of a homeowner as defined in § 9–105 of this article.
“Business property” means real property:

subparagraph.text: that has been assigned a commercial use code by the Department; and
for which the total State, county, municipal corporation, and special taxing district property taxes for the taxable year do not exceed $100,000.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title:

paragraph.text: the governing body of a county shall provide a semiannual payment schedule for State, county, and special taxing district property taxes due on owner–occupied residential property or business property; and

the governing body of a municipal corporation shall provide a semiannual payment schedule for municipal corporation and special taxing district property taxes due on owner–occupied residential property or business property.

subsection.text: A semiannual payment schedule under this section shall apply:

paragraph.text: at the time of the transfer of property purchased on or after July 1, 2000; and
to any current or future owner of owner–occupied residential property or business property, regardless of whether the property was purchased before July 1, 2000.
The semiannual payment schedule under this section shall apply to:

subparagraph.text: the property tax due for the tax year following transfer of the property; and
the property tax due and not in arrears for the current tax year for any transfer occurring on or after July 1 but on or before September 30.

paragraph.text: The first installment of a semiannual payment shall be paid on or before September 30.

subsection.text: A semiannual payment schedule may include a service charge to be paid with the second installment.
A service charge:

paragraph.text: shall be:

subparagraph.text: adopted by the taxing authority that collects the property taxes after obtaining the prior approval of the amount of the service charge from the Department, as part of adoption of the property tax rate under §§ 6–301 through 6–303 of this article;
applicable to all property tax being collected by the taxing authority on the semiannual payment schedule for itself and for any other taxing authority;
expressed as a percent of the amount of tax due at the second installment and shown on the tax bill as a percent and actual dollar amount charged; and
calculated in an amount:

sub-subparagraph.text: reasonably equivalent to the anticipated lost interest income associated with the 3–month delay in payment of the second installment by multiplying the amount of the second installment by a rate not exceeding 1.5%; and

covering administrative expenses associated with the semiannual payment not exceeding the lesser of the actual expenses incurred in the preceding fiscal year per semiannual tax account as approved by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation or 10% of the charge for the anticipated lost interest income as calculated in item 1 of this item;

paragraph.text: does not apply if both installments of property tax are paid on or before September 30 of the taxable year; and
may not be considered to be a property tax for the purposes of any provision of a local law or charter that limits the property tax rate or property tax revenues.

subsection.text: The local taxing authority shall provide to the Department by May 1 of each year, information that substantiates that the proposed service charge for the anticipated lost interest is reasonably equivalent to the amount of interest that will be lost as a result of the semiannual payment.

paragraph.text: The property tax bill under a semiannual payment schedule:

subparagraph.text: shall state:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount of the tax due if paid in full, including any applicable discounts for early payment;
the amount of the tax due if paid in semiannual installments, including any applicable discounts for early payment of the first installment;
the amount of any service charge to be paid with the second installment unless the second installment is paid on or before September 30 of the taxable year;
that the service charge does not apply if both installments are paid on or before September 30 of the taxable year; and
the date the tax payment is due; and

subparagraph.text: shall be subject to approval by the Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: The Department shall approve any local semiannual payment schedule collection that:

subparagraph.text: provides efficient and cost–effective collection of taxes; and
provides two semiannual coupons, two semiannual billing forms, or a similar method that allows taxpayers to pay on a semiannual basis.

paragraph.text: Local semiannual payment schedule collection systems that are not approved by the Department shall utilize 2 semiannual payment coupons that shall be submitted with the appropriate payment.

subsection.text: A payment under a semiannual schedule:

paragraph.text: for the first installment:

subparagraph.text: is due on July 1 of the tax year; and
may be paid without interest on or before September 30 of the tax year; and

paragraph.text: for the second installment:

subparagraph.text: is due on December 1 of the tax year;
except for the service charge, may be paid without interest on or before December 31 of the tax year; and
may be prepaid without the service charge or interest on or before September 30 of the tax year.

paragraph.text: If an escrow account is established for the payment of the property tax, the escrow account servicer shall pay tax in semiannual installments unless the escrow account servicer has received written direction from the property owner or borrower to pay property tax in annual payments.

If a taxpayer provides written direction to an escrow account servicer at least 60 days prior to the beginning of the tax year, property taxes shall be paid on an annual payment basis on behalf of that taxpayer by the escrow account servicer in the tax year that begins immediately following the year in which the written direction was received.

If a taxpayer provides written direction to an escrow account servicer less than 60 days prior to the beginning of the tax year, property taxes may be paid on an annual payment basis on behalf of that taxpayer by the escrow account servicer in the tax year that begins immediately following the year in which the written direction was received.

The governing body of Prince George’s County may authorize, by law, an installment payment schedule of no more than six payments each year for county, municipal, and special taxing district property taxes due on owner–occupied residential property owned by a homeowner if:

subparagraph.text: the homeowner is at least 62 years old; and
the owner–occupied residential property is not subject to a deed of trust, mortgage, or other encumbrance.

paragraph.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County shall provide, by law, for:

subparagraph.text: any additional eligibility criteria for the installment payment schedule under this subsection;
the process for electing an installment payment schedule;
the due date of each payment installment; and
any other provision necessary to carry out the provisions of this subsection.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of Charles County may authorize, by law, a payment deferral of the county property tax for residential real property occupied as the principal residence of the owner.
An owner is eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section if the owner or at least 1 of the owners:

paragraph.text: has resided in the dwelling for a period of at least 5 consecutive years; and
meets the income and age eligibility requirements determined under subsection (c) of this section.

subsection.text: If the governing body of Charles County authorizes a payment deferral under this section, the governing body shall specify:

paragraph.text: the minimum age of an owner to determine eligibility for the payment deferral;
the amount of the tax that may be deferred, not exceeding the increase in the county property tax from the date the taxpayer elects to defer the payment of the tax;
the duration of the payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section;

restrictions on the amount of the real property eligible for a payment deferral, except that the amount of eligible property may not be less than the dwelling and curtilage, as determined by the supervisor;
the rate of interest to be paid on the county property tax payment from the due date without a deferral until the date that the county property tax is paid;
that any mortgagee or beneficiary under a deed of trust be entitled to receive notice of the deferral and of the amount of tax to be deferred; and
the level of income to determine eligibility for the payment deferral.

subsection.text: The county property tax that is deferred under this section and any interest specified in subsection (c)(5) of this section are due:

paragraph.text: when the eligible owner dies; or
immediately upon transfer of ownership of the property for which the property tax has been deferred.

subsection.text: The governing body of Charles County shall specify the cumulative amount of the deferral and related interest in the taxpayer’s annual property tax bill.

paragraph.text: A lien shall attach to the property in the amount of all deferred taxes and interest.
The lien shall remain attached until the deferred taxes and interest are paid.
The governing body of Charles County shall authorize the deferral by written agreement.
The agreement shall reflect the terms and conditions of the deferral, including notice of the lien.
The agreement shall be recorded in the land records of the county.

subsection.text: Penalties may not be charged during the period of the deferral on any tax payments deferred under this section.

Notwithstanding Subtitle 1 of this title, the governing body of Washington County may authorize, by law, a payment deferral of the county property tax for residential real property occupied as the principal residence of the owner.
An owner is eligible for a payment deferral under subsection (a) of this section if the owner or at least one of the owners:

paragraph.text: has resided in the dwelling for a period of at least 5 consecutive years;

subsection.text: If the governing body of Washington County authorizes a payment deferral under this section, the governing body shall specify:
